notesStmt.note: 'The English moor' (E.1782[1]) and 'The love-sick court'(E.1782[2]) have separate title pages, continuous pagination and register, and a final leaf of epilogue. 'Covent Garden weeded' (E.1782[3]) and 'The nevv academy' (E.1782[4]) have separate title pages, continous register, separate pagination, and a final leaf of advertisements. 'Covent garden weeded' has t.p. which reads: 'The weeding of the Covent-Garden'. 'The queen and concubine' (E.1782[5]) has its own t.p., continous pagination and register, and a final leaf of advertisements.

div.p: THE NEW ACADEMY, Or, the NEW Exchange.
LONDON, Printed or Andrew Crook, at the Green Dragon in Saint ●auls Church-yard: And Henry Brome at the Gun in Ivy-lane. 1658.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item: Sir Swithin Whimlby, a melancholy Widower. Suitor to the Lady Neſtlecock.
Old Matchil, a Merchant that married his Maid. Gabri|alla's Guardian.
Young Matchil his ſonne.
Old Lafoy a French Gentleman, Guardian to young Matchil.
Young F. Lafoy his ſonne.
Mr. Hardyman, Captain Valentines Father-in-law. Han|nah's father.
Strigood, half brother to Matchil.
Valentine Askal, ſon-in-law to Hardiman. Hannah's half-brother.
Eraſmus a young Gentleman, his Companion and Friend.
Caſh, Matchils Prentice.
Nehemiah Neſtlecock, a fooliſh Gentleman, the Ladies ſonne.
Ephraim, the Lady Neſtlecocks Servant.
Rafe Camelion an uxorious Citizen.

list.head: VVomen.
list.item: Ladie Neſtlecock, a fond Mother.
Mrs. Blithe Tripſhort, Sir Swithin Whimlbies Neece.
Hannah, Camelions wife, Captain Hardimans daughter.
Maudlin, Matchils Maid and Wife.

div.head: THE NEW ACADEMY, OR, THE NEW EXCHANGE.
Act. I.
div.p: _IS this the entertainment you promiſ'd me in the Jovial Mer|chants houſe? Is this the great intereſt you have in his huge hoſ|pitality? when by half an hours attendance and intreats, we can|not obtain the ſight of him.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: I wonder at it; Sure ſome ſtrange diſaſter has ſuddenly befallen him. He was, laſt night the merrieſt man alive, drank healthes; told tales; ſung Catches; Trowle the Bowle; Toſſe the Cannykin; and what not! and all for joy, that his ſonne, he ſaid, was upon his returne, whom he has not ſeen theſe dozen years, ſince he ſent him a little Lad into France, to be bred there.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
I heard he did ſo; and that in lieu, by way of
Exchange, he brings up the daughter of the Pariſien that breeds his ſonne.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But is that daughter ſo exquiſite a creature, as is this Merchant Matchills own whom you ſo much extoll?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: They are both ſo equally handſome, and ver|tuous, that, be their dowries ſo, and their conſents alike, I'll take my choice of croſſe and pile for either, with ſuch a friend as thou art.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Troth, and that's friendly ſpoken, Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: It is ſo Val. yet not with ſome policie do I wiſh thee a fortune: for, inſooth. young Gentleman, though I like your perſon, and ſome of your qualities, yet by reaſon of your wants, I finde you ſomething heavy on my purſe-ſtrings; and my ſelfe ſcarce able to ſupply you. And, if we faile of good matches, I muſt even turne you over ſhortly to the hopes you hoaſt of in your City-Myſtreſſes and Tradeſmens wives—.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace, prythee hold thy peace.
Friend Caſh! Is your Maſter, Mr. Matchill yet at leiſure 〈◊〉 be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.p: He much deſires, ſir, to be held excuſ'd. 'Tis true that he invited you. His dinner's ready; and his heart welcomes you. But he has met with an unhap|py newes to day.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I feard ſome ill. What is the mat|ter?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: His only ſonne, whom he of late expect|ed home out of France, we hear, is dead.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: His daughter will prove a bouncing match then.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: That's the impreſſion the heavy newes makes in you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, although my Maſters ſud|den ſadneſſe ſhuts him from you. His meat and wine are ready. There are ſome good company in his Par|lour too, Pray ſtay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Are his faire daughter, and the French-borne
Damſel there to be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: Both. Pray be pleaſ'd to enter.
I hope his paſſionate fit e're you have din'd will be paſt over. He is not wont to ſuffer long under the hand of ſorrow.
sp.l: 'Tis like that you ſhall ſee him ere you go.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: In that faire hope we'll enter and fall to.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: 'Tis like you ſhall fall ſhort though of your aim
At my young Myſtreſſe, who by this black newes,
Becomes my Maſters heire, and ſo the white
That all the gallant ſuiters of the City
And Court will level their keen ſhafts at. Where
Are mine own hopes then, that ſtood as faire
In competition for her, love as any,
When the great noiſe of her inheritance,
Shall drown each Lovers tongue, that cannot ſay,
It is a Lords at leaſt, I rather wiſh
The young man had not did.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Where's my Boykin? my Friskoe? my De|light? my Caſh? by what better name can I call thee?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.p: O me! Maſter Strigood, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I come to comfort my brother in his ſor|row.
His ſonne is dead, they ſay. Ha! Is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And he is almoſt dead with ſorrow: Back ſir.
The ſight of you, that are his ſole vexation, will make him mad.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: That is my way to cure him.
Madneſſe drowns grief in any man.—Probatum.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Good Mr. Strigood depart.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Good Mr. Caſh, and Mr. Matchils man.
I'll ſee your Maſter. What! deny his brother?
His nowne natural brother? By the ſurer ſide too
We tumbled in one Pannier; though we had
Two Rippiers, Sweet ſir, I am the elder too
Strigood was in my mother before Matchill
Therefore, becauſe I have ſpent an eſtate
And he has got-one, muſt not I maintain
My ſelf the better man?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Yes: if you had the wherewithal.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Sir, you had been as good ha' held your tongue.
Lend me ſome money Caſh.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I have no money, ſir, but what's my Ma|ſters.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Whoſe money, ſir, was that you played laſt night.
Among the Knights and Braveries at the ordinary?
Gold by the handfuls, Caſh! Lend me two pieces.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Speak lower, ſir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me three pieces, Caſh.
Before I ſpeak too loud, whoſe money's that
You uſe to weare abroad at Feaſts and Revels
In ſilver lace and ſatten; though you wait
At home in ſimple Serge, or broad-cloth, ſir.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Be not ſo loud, I pray.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Lend me five pieces.
I ſhall grow louder elſe. Who payes your Barber?
I mean not for your Prentice pig-hair'd cut
Your weare at home here; but your Periwigs;
Your locks and Lady-ware that dangle in 'em,
Like ſtraws in the buſh natural of a Bedlem?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: What mean you Mr. Strygood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I mean ten pieces now; I'll go no leſſe. Do not I know your haunts?—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You may; you train'd one to 'em

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Do not I know your our leaps, and vagaries?
Your tiring houſes, where you ſhift your ſelf,
Your privy lodgings, for your trunks and punks?
Your midnight walks and meetings? Come, the money.
And, heark thee, though thou modeſt my brother by't.
I'll keep thy councel: thou ſhalt finde me yertuous.
I want, he gives me nothing; and thou canſt not
Do him better ſervice, then relieve his brother.

sp.speaker: Caſh:
sp.l: I am in; and muſt, to hide my old faults, do
Like an ill Painter, lawbe 'em o're with new.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Quickly. I ſhall grow loud again elſe Caſh.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Sir, I am in your hands, here are ten pieces.
I hope you will not think my Maſter for▪●●.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: No; no for all he has that comes through thy hands.
My nimble Caſh; and from his I am ſure,
Though I were ſtarving, I ſhould finger nothing.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Will you go now?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: I'll ſee him e're I go,
And dine, if there be meat i'th' houſe. What eate's
Are there within ●'ll draw a knife amon● 'em.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: This deſperate old Ruſſian, would undo me,
But he hopes to waſte his brother by me.
He has ſpent himſelf to beggery; and would fall ſo,
But that he has pernicious fire in's brain,
That raging ſpreads to ruine others with him.
I muſt beware of him,
Is ſhe come too?
Then 'tis deereed, my Maſter muſt, from ſorrow, ſuffer in madneſſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go home Ephraim.
And have a care you ſuffer not my boy
To Straggle forth 'mong his unhappy play-mates,
For fear of miſchief.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: It ſhall be my care.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What do you lock up my brother, ha?—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: H' has lock't himſelf up, Madam; and will ſuffer
None to come at him, till his ſorrowful fit
Be ſomewhat over.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Not's own Siſter, ha?—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Nor his half brother neither: yet he's here.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Is he here, ha? That Strygood? Is he here?
Hang him old reprobate. And beſhrew thy heart,
For a young varlet, to call him our brother.
It is no marvel, if my brother Matchil
Lock up himſelf, and ſuch a wickedneſſe
Be in his houſe, as is that Strygood, ha—
Let him take heed, he comes not in my Nayl reach,
And call me Siſter, or my Brother, brother,
Like a debauſh'd old Villain, as he is.
O that my husband Neſtlecock were alive,
But for three minutes, to ſend him to
Newgate, if he preſume to call me Siſter
But I command you in my husbands name,
Who was a Juſtice, when he liv'd, to thruſt him
Out of your Maſters doors, my brothers houſe.
Leſt I be ſick with the loath'd ſight of him.
You will not diſobey this, will you, ha?—
If not, why ſtir you not? ha.—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I muſt remove
This fit of hers. There's but one way to do it;
And thats to talk of her white boy, ſhe's fond on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you not ſend him packing, ha?—

sp.speaker: Caſh,
sp.l: Firſt, Madam.
(By your good Ladiſhips leave) how does your ſonne
Sweet Maſter Nehemiah Neſtlecock?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you courteous friend. In truth, laſt night,
One of my Coach-gueldings fell lame, and I,
By that conſtrain'd to come afoot,
Was forc'd to leave my boy at home; or elſe
He had come with me, to have been a comfort
To his ſad Uncle: But I would not now
For twice my Gueldings price, my childe were here;
And that foule fiend i'th' houſe, whoſe very looks
Would fright him into ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: O good Lady!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I can't ſo ſoon forget the fright he took
At ſeeing the roguiſh Jugler once eat tow,
And blow it out of's mouth in fire and ſmoke,
He lay a fourtnight by't.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: That's two yeares ſince.
And he was then but young, he's now a man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alack a childe; but going in's nineteenth year.
Where's my Neece Joyce?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Within there Madam; ſo is Gabriella
The French young Gentlewoman to attend you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'll ſtay with them till I may ſee my brother.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I hope old Strygood, who now on the ſudden
Hath ſlipt her memory, meets her by the eares firſt.
sp.stage: Enter Matchil, an opeu letter in his hands.
sp.l: But the good minute's come, before I look't for't.
My Maſter now appears. He looks moſt ſourely
Expreſſing more of anger then of grief.
I feare, old Strygood was ſo loud with me,
That he hath over-heard us, and I ſhall break
Before I am a Freeman.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sorrow be gone
And puleing grief away, whileſt I take in
A nobler and more manly Paſſion;
Anger, that may inſtruct me to revenge.
My childe is loſt by treacherous neglect
In that falſe Frenchman, to whoſe ſeeming care
I truſted the chief comfort of my life;
My boy. Nay, read again. 'Tis written, here,
He was grown man:

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: His man, I think, he ſaid.
sp.stage: Caſh liſtens to Match|il, and ſpeaks aſide.
sp.l: Does your man trouble you. I do not like that

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And here he writes that in his youthful ſpring
And heat of ſpirit, he began to grow
Intemperate and wilde—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Wilde! Are you there?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Which drew him on to riotous expence—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And there again, to riotous expence!
'Tis I directly that he's troubled with.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And ſometimes into quarrels. What o' that?
In all this he was ſtill mine own. Oboy—

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Some ſlave has writ ſome fearful information.
Againſt me, and he hugs and kiſſes it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And had his Guardian had a feeling care
(Hang his French friendſhip) over my dear childe,
As I had over his, theſe youthful follies
Might have been temper'd into manly vertues.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I hear not that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I fall back agen
From my revenge to grief. Away; I will not.
Here's the death-doing point. Theſe ſlight diſorders.
In my young forward ſonne (I finde it here)
Were, by his churliſh and perfidious Guardian,
Interpreted no leſſe then Reptobation,
And, by his ignorant cruelty, ſo puniſh'd.
For, here he ſhuts his eare and door againſt him:
When ſuddenly the looſe licentious world
Soothes on his youthful, in judicious courage
To imminent deſtruction; ſo being engag'd
In a raſh quarrel, he in duel fell.
Th' Opponents ſword was inſtrument; yet I inferre.
Lafoy, his Guarcian was his murderer.
Farewel, my boy; and this is the laſt teare
Thou ſhalt wring from me. Something I'll do,
Shall ſhew a fathers love, and valour too.
I'm young enough to draw a ſword in France, yet.
But firſt—Come hither, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Now it comes.

sp.speaker: Mrt.
sp.l: I purpoſe ſtreight to order my eſtate
Look that you forthwith perfect my Accompts;
And bring me all my books of debtor and creditor,
Receipts and payments, what you have in wares,
And what in caſh, let me inform my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: 'Tis as I fear'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll ſet all right and ſtreight,
All ſtatutes, bonds, bills, and ſeal'd inſtruments
That do concern me, I have in my Cloſet
Or at my Councels, or my Scriveners.
I'll call in them my ſelfe. Why doeſt thou look ſo amaz'dly?
Would'ſt have me yield a reaſon? why, I'll tell thee
I mean to make a voyage; and, perhaps,
To ſettle and proportion out my eſtate
By Will, before I go. Do you as I command you.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Whatever he pretends, I know his drift:
And, e'te I'll be diſcover'd by my ſtay;
Being run out, I'll chooſe to run away.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My daughter in the firſt place muſt be car'd for.
I'll make her a good match. My next in blood then,
My Knave-half-brother, and my whole fool-Siſter.
But the beſt is, her Ladiſhip has enough;
And all I have, in Strygoods hands, were nothing.
Therefore I'll purpoſe nothing to him. Oh.
The Joy and Torment of my life, at once
Appear to me. I muſt divide them, thus.
Hence hated iſſue of my mortal foe
VVhom I have foſter'd with a Parents Piety
As carefully and dearly as mine own.
VVhile the inhumane cruelty of thy Sire
Has to untimely death expoſ'd my ſonne.
Thank me I kill not thee; ſo leave my houſe.
There's French enough in town, that may befriend you.
To pack you o're to Paris; what's your own
Take w'ye, and go. VVhy cleave you to her ſo?
Forſake her, caſt her off. Are not my words
Of force, but I muſt uſe my hands to part ye?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Deare, honour'd father, I beſeech you hear me.
In parting us you ſeparate life from me,
And therein act a real crueltie
On me your only childe, ſharper then that,
Which you can but pretend done by her father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Durſt thou ſpeak ſo?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I cannot live from her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O monſtrous. Pray, your reaſon. Why not live?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You know, Sir, from our Infancie we have been,
Bred up together, by your tender care
As we had been twin-borne, and equally
Your own; and by a ſelf-ſame education,
We have grown hitherto, in one affection,
We are hoth but one body, and one mind,
What Gabriella was, I was, what I, was ſhe.
And, till this hapleſſe houre, you have enjoyn'd me,
Nay, charg'd me on your bleſſing, not to arrogate
More of your love unto my ſelf, then her,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That was, 'cauſe I preſum'd her father lov'd,
Or ſhould have lov'd my ſonne, your brother.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I never knew brother, or ſiſter, I;
Nor my poor ſelf, but in my Gabrella.
Then blame me not to love her, I beſeech you
—Upon me knees.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Th' art knee-deep in rebellion.
Unnatural Gipſie, ſince thou prov'ſt my torment
In being the ſame with her; and haſt declar'd
Thy ſelf no more my childe, then ſhe, whom now
I do abhorre, avoid, with her, my ſight.
Riſe, and be gone, leſt thou pull curfes on thee
Shall ſink thee into earth.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: O rather, Sir.
Let me, 'gainſt whom your fury firſt was bent
Suffer alone the ſharpneſſe of your vengeance:
And let it not be ſaid, 'cauſe you ſurmiſe,
My father loſt your ſon, that, therefore, you
Have caſt away your daughter. Hurl me, rather,
Into the ruthleſs waves to ſeek my way;
Or do but take her, hold her in the armes
Of your paternal love, and I'll take flight
To weane her to you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: She cannot, may not leave me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Out of my doors then, with her.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What's the matter? ha—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Such as you cannot mend, deare Lady Siſter.
What come you hither with your Ha—for? Ha—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To comfort you, dear brother, if you'll heare me.
Your ſonne is dead, they ſay; and here I finde
Your daughter is rebellious 'gainſt; our will.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You ſpeak much comfort, do you not, think you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But is it ſo Joyce? ha!—I thought you, Joyce,
Would have rejoyc'd your father in obedience, Joyce;
And not afflict him with your ſtubbornneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O this impertinent woman!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But my brother,
Let me adviſe you, rather then ſuffer her
To be an eye-ſore to you, put her out,
Where ſhe may learne more duty. If you pleaſe
I'll take her home, and ſhew her how it ſhould be

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes, as you have ſhewen your Neſtlecock, your ſonne.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I, there's a childe! Brother, you'l pardon me,
If I aſpire in hope, that he ſhallbe
Your heire, if Joyce miſcarry in rebellion.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And therefore you would breed her. How the devil
Works in a covetous woman! Though a foole too.
Your ſonne's an Aſſe; an Ideot; and your ſelf
No better, that have bred him ſo. Do you tell me
Of your ſweet ſugar-chop't Neſtle cockſcombe?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He's fit t' inherit nothing but a place
I'th' Spittle-houſe, Fools Colledge, yond, at Knights|bridge.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And did I come to bring thee conſolation?
Now let me tell thee, I rejoyce in thy
Juſt puniſhment, thy ſcourge of croſſes. Thou,
That for theſe ſix years ſpace▪ until this day,
Haſt kept continual feaſt and jollitie
For thy wives death, who was too good for thee.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Right, for ſhe was my Maſter, a perpe●●●l
Vexation to me, while ſhe was above-ground
Your Ladiſhip could not have ſpoke more comfort to me
Then the remembrance of that ſhook-off Shackle,
Which now, in my affliction makes me ſmile,
And were I on her grave, I could cut capers.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A further puniſhment, I pr●●hecie
Grows in the neck of thy leud inſolence

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I could e'ne finde in heart to marry again,
In ſpight, now, of thy witchcraft, my ſon dead!
My daughter diſobedient! and your childe
A very chilblaine. What have I to do
But marry again: all women are not devil●,
I may yet get an heire unto my minde.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Art thou here too—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stay, you forget your brother, Mr. Matchil.
You have match'd ill once already; and take heed
You match not worſe, your children, though un|toward.
And taking of the devilliſh Shrew, their mother,
Were likely of your own begetting; Yet
Your ſecond wife may bring you a ſupply
Of heires, but who muſt get them, firſt is doubtful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thy impudence amazes me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I'm ſick at ſight of the leud Reprobate.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Dee caſt about for heirs; and have beſides
Your daughter here, a brother and a ſiſter?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Call not thy ſelf our brother. He appears
U●●●nde to me, but thou inſufferable,
I loath to look upon thee.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He has ſpoke
sp.p: Againſt her Aunt, her Moon-calf ſonne. I'll make her love me beſt, and preſently.
sp.l: Brother, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot look upon thee.
Provoke me not to ●●eech, I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Give me leave to ſpeak; Hold you your peace;
Hear but my brotherly advice; and when
Give your conſent in ſilence.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hear him not.

sp.speaker: (Mat.)
sp.l: Nor you neither, hum—hum—hum.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I am not angry with you now; and therefore
I charge you, hear him not.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: My advice is thus, that for your daughters good.
For mine own good, and for your Siſters good.
And for her ſonne, your Nephew's good.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How's that? ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And chiefly for your own good, and the credit
A wiſe man would deſire to hold i'th' world,
Think not of marrying, nor of buying hornes
At the whole value of your whole eſtate,
But match your daughter while you have the meanes
In your own hands; give her a good round portion,
Here are deſerving Gentlemen i'th' houſe.
Next, think of me your brother, that has ſpent
In down-right fellowſhip (heaven knows what
All fraudulent purpoſes to make any man
A miſer or a gainer by't) a faire eſtate.
And now do want a brotherly ſupply.
A hundred a year or ſo: but above all
Faſten your land unto yout Siſters ſonne.
That hopeful Gentleman, ſweet Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Now brother you may hear him.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: What though it ſtraggle from the name of Matchil.
Remember yet he is your mothers Grandchilde.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why dee not hear him, brother?—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As I hope
To be a landed man my ſelf,
Had I a thouſand yearly, I would leav't him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Trulie, I thank you. Now I'll call you brother.
Y'are a good natur'd Gentleman if you had it.
Come home, and ſee my ſonne.—VVill you not hear him? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I need not, nor your ſelfe. I ſee you gape
Like monſters that would ſwallow me alive.
I know your mindes; and I will do mine own.
And, thus it is. Stay, let me ſtay a little.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Look you how wilde he looks.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: He's falling mad.
Stark ſtaring mad,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would he had a wife then,
For nothing elſe can tame him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So it ſhall be.
Firſt, I'll be Maſter of mine own eſtate.
Next—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Take a wife to maſter that, and you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Next, you Madamoiſelle, (on whom with pa|tience
I cannot look) forſake my houſe, and ſuddenly;
Linger not for a man to wait upon you,
But let your black bag guard you, 'tis a faſhion
Begun amongſt us here by your own Nation.
And if I longer muſt call you my daughter,
Forſake you her.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: VVhat mine own heart? dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: At your own choice. I can force her depar|ture,
Though not perſwade your ſtay, determine quickly
Either to leave her, and enjoy a father,
Or never more expect a fathers bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Dear, mine own heart, leave me, obey your father.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: It muſt be to my death then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll be ſudden.
Therefore be you as brief in your reſolve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, poor hearts. Juſt ſo loth
To part was I and my ſonne Nehemiah
Today when I came forth.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Neece Joyce, let me
Adviſe you.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, none of your advices.
Let her adviſe her ſelf; whileſt I impart
To you my next intention; which is thus.
To end your ſtrife for ſhares in mine eſtate
I'll venter on a wife: indeed I'll marry

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Will you ſo? ha!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes indeed La,—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: If then
You'l eſtate nothing on me for my life
Give me a ſee to help you to a wife,
I can, a good one.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll none, Sir, of your good ones.
Beſides, Sir, I'm provided.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are not, are you? ha

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let it ſuffice, I ſay't, ſo quit my houſe.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Shall I expect then nothing?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray ſir, do.
'Tis all I can afford you. You have wit,
Yes, you can daunce, tread money out of ruſhes,
Slight and activity to live upon.
A nimble braine, quick hands and airie heels
To get a living.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Hah.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pray fall to practice.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I may, ſir, to your coſt, if you put off
Your daughter with her Sweet-heart, her Mon Coeur
There, as ſhe calls her. Dear, my Lady Siſter;
You ſee how churliſhly this Merchant uſes us.
He has forgot, ſure, he was borne a Gentleman.
Will you be pleaſ'd, I ſpeak to you in your eare.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Any way, brother Strigood, Hang him, Nabal,
To warn me out o's houſe; and not alone,
To turne a ſtranger from within his gates,
But offer to caſt out his childe too, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis about that I'd ſpeak, pray Madam heark you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Noble Mr. Matchil, though we are your meat
Before we ſaw you you will give us leave
To take our leaves, and thank you ere we part.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: W'have heard your cauſe of ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But I have over-paſt it. Heark ye Gentlemen

sp.speaker: Eraſ.
sp.l: You'l give us leave firſt to ſalute the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, if you love me, heare me firſt.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Your will, Sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Neece, you ſhall no way diſobey your father
In being rul'd by me.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, ſo, it takes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You and your ſecond ſelfe ſhall home with me
Until his furious humour be blown over.
To which the firſt meanes is to 〈◊〉 his fight,
And then let me alone to make your peace.

sp.speaker: Joy. Gab.
sp.l: We thank your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: So let us ſlip.
Home to my houſe together.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Hiſt brother, lead the way.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: As glad as ever Fox was of his prey

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis even ſo, Gentlemen, ſorrow findes no lodging.
In my light heart ſometimes ſhe knocks at door,
And takes a drink, but here ſhe muſt not ſit by't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Y' are happy Sir.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet I have heard you ſay
You never taſted joy for divers yeares
Till your wife died: ſince when, a King of mirth,
And now to marry agen is ſuch a thing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Yes ſir, tis ſuch a thing that I will marry
That I fore know can never diſobey me
And I'll defie the devil to diſhoneſt her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo ougly?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, he means ſo vertuous.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-ſaid, ſir, you ſhall drink before me. Ra|chel, Mawdlin.
sp.l: 'Proteſt you ſhall though't be in my own houſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now he reſumes his humour.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ratchel I ſay,
Bring me a kan o' ſack.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But how can you
Preſume before the dangerous marriage-trial
That ſhe whom y'have choſen will be obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: D' ye think he has not tried her? There's a queſtion

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-ſaid agen. I was about to ſay ſo.
Rachel, ſome ſack, I ſay. Yes, I have tried her, ſir,
Tri'd her, and tri'd her again; all over and over
Theſe five yeares day and night; and ſtill obedient.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Then you are ſure to her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I never uſ'd
A marriage-queſtion, not a woing word,
But do all by command, ſhe is ſo obedient.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And yet ſhe's chaſte and vertuous withal.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-ſaid again, ſir, ſo I was a ſaying.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But we have talk't away the Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: No matter, let'hem go. Would they were far enough.
sp.stage: Enter Rachel, ſilver Kan and Napkin.
sp.p: Come, the ſack, the ſack.—Who taught you that courteſie maid.
sp.l: Pray try a better to the Gentleman.
Proteſt you ſhall begin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In your own houſe, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: ●'ll rather g' ye my houſe, then break my word in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Y' are Lord here, and may command me, ſir. And ſo my ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'll do you reaſon, ſir.
Be ready with your Napkin, and a lower douke maid.
I'll hang dead weight at your buttocks elſe. So.
Is not this obedience, Gentlemen, Mr. Eraſmus?
Mus, I will call thee Mus, I love to be
Familiar, where I love; and Godamercy
For your friend here; you both ſhall ſee my daugh|ter.
But my French Damoſel and I are parted
I hope by this time. So here's to you Mus.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: To me, to me, to me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ha boy, art there? diſpatch
Your court'ſie quickly, and go cal my daughter.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: She is gone forth, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Forth, ha? when? whither?
La ye, ſhe thinks I'm angry, and the finger
Is in the eye already. Is not this
Feare and obedience, Gentlemen? who went with her.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: She went with my Lady Neſtlecock, to bring Gabriella on her way they ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would
They were all in France together.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She comes again, I doubt not. Dry your eyes.
And drink that ſack, without a court'ſie, drink it.
You do not know my meaning, Gentlemen.
Stay: now gi' me't agen.—Now go and dry
Your face within—without a court'ſie? ha!
Now is not this obedience, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But this is not the rare obedient peece
That you will marry?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You do not hear me ſay ſo.
But I preſume, as much obedience
In her I have made choice of.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Marrie a maid.
And we will be her Hench-boyes, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, I'll have no ſuch blades 'bout my wives hanches.
But come, to end this tedious Scene, in which
I ha' paſt the Purgatorie of my Paſſions
Of ſorrow, anger, feare, and hope at laſt.
I am refin'd, ſublim'd, exalted, fixt
In my true Sphere of mirth; where love's my object.
And bloodie thought of black revenge caſt by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Could your faire breaſt harbour a bloody thought?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: For ſome few minutes, in which extaſie
I meant t' ha' gone, as other Gallants do.
To fight in France, forſooth, and charg'd my man
To draw up his Accompts, call in my moneys,
Thought to have made my Will—.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I ſaw your Caſhier
Go forth e'ne now with a ſttong luſty Porter
Loaden with money: I will not ſay my teeth
Water'd at it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But 'twas enough to make
A very true mans fingers itch.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I cannot
Think he is run away; but yet I like not
His carrying forth, when I ſay, fetch in money.
But this is from my purpoſe. Love ye mirth?
Let's in, and drink, and talk. That gives it birth.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I prithee now, I prithee, prithie now
Urge me no more in this caſe; for I cannot,
Nor I wo' not ſo I wo' not, I be jealous
Oſ mine own wife, mine own deat fleſh and blood?
That's ſuch a thing! I pidee ſpeak no more on't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You ſhew you love Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So I hope I do Nan.
My cock, my pity nittle nanſie cockſie,
Do I not ſhew my love when I deny thee
Vnreaſonable requeſts? I never heard
Of woman that deſir'd a loving husband
To be a jealous Maſter over her.
Eſpecially a City-Shopkeeper.
The beſt part of whoſe trade runs through the hands
Of his faire wife too! 'Tis unreaſonable.
And thou the ſirſt that e're take up the humour.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you the ſirſt that e're I knew beſotted
Into a wilful confidence, which renders
Me to a vile conſtruction; and your ſelfe
By leaving me to all aſſaults and hazards
Have got the reputation of a Wittal.
Or one that ſeems contented to become ſo.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Cock, my Nanſie Cock, my Cockſie Nanſie,
Kiſſe me, and uſe thine own conſcience: I ſcorn
The yellow ſickneſſe, I, let 'hem all ſay what they will.
D'einty, come thou to me. I will not loſe
An haires bredth o' my humour, nor retain
An ill thought o' my Cocks honeſtie
For all the wealth i' the Exchange, not I

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I not deſire you ſhould, but only that
You will not ſeem ſo careleſſe of my credit,
Expoſing me to all temptations
Of the wilde Gallantry of the wanton time.
By whom (although my chaſtity remaines
Untouch't) my name and your diſcretion ſuffers.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh, Honi ſoit again: Cock, I defie
Calumniation and detraction I.
When I am jealous, let the horne-curſe take me;
And let me be with hornets ſtung to death.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Still you flie from the point, I would not have
You vex your ſelf with cauſeleſſe jealouſie
Over my conſtant love; but only ſeem
A little watchful o're my reputation.
Whereby you may decline mens leud attempts.
And not to throw me upon opportunities
To draw them on; as if I were a thing
S●● out, as in your ſhop, for common ſale.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, Thou ſhalt never tie me to't: not I.
I muſt not loſe my harmleſſe recreations
Abroad to ſnook over my wife at home.
Thought'ſt ha' me like the hair-brain'd Point-tagger,
That uſ'd to hammer his fingers at one end
O'th' ſhop, while's wife was bargaining at the other?
Not I; ſweet Cock, pidee lets heare no more on't.
Now friend! Is your buſineſſe to me or my wife?

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.l: This Superſcription will inform you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: To my deare daughter Mrs. Hannah Camelion, at her ſhop or houſe in or near the New Ex|change.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Take it quickly, what a Knave art thou to put a letter in my hands, that is directed to my wife. Sbobs I would not ha' open'd it for fonrty pound.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.p: If all husbands in the City were of his minde, it were a Forreſt of fooles indeed.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I muſt leave thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Pray ſtay a little. This letter's from my fa|ther.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I hope the good Captaine's well.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, very well, pray read his Letter here.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, you ſhall pardon me. Not I.
I have a match to play at the ducking-pond.
Prithee fore-ſlow not my occaſions, Cock,
As I forbear to pry into thy ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: Here's nothing but what I would have you ſee.
There's for your poſtage, friend. It needs no an|ſwer.

sp.speaker: Poſt.
sp.l: I thank you, Myſtris.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But if you will not ſtay to reade this Let|ter.
You ſhall not deny me one thing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What is it, quickly? my ſweet Nanny Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here, take this pen: write here a word or ſentence.
What you pleaſe. But keep it well in minde,
And look that you be ſure to know't agen
When I ſhall ſhew't you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: 'Tis done, there: I defie, and dare the de|vil and all his Clerks to counterfeit my hand. So, my ſweet Cock, a kiſſe and adieu.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well Rafe, remember that you won't be jea|lous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, Sbobs yonder comes one of the Blades,
That thou would'ſt have me have an eye to; He
That lives by his wits, and yet is ſeldom ſober:
That goes ſo gallantly, and has no credit,
Nor ever buyes with ready money; But
Barters commodity for commodity.
(Such as it is) with Tradeſmens wives, they ſay.
What call you him, oh Askal; there's another
Comes with him too. Into thy ſhop, good Cock.
I wo' not ſtay, not I. So, farewel Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And farewel Coxſcombe, ſome wife would ſay now.
I am much troubled at his ſillineſſe.
And would to right me, ſtraine a womans wit,
Knew I with modeſty how to anſwer it.
Something I'le do.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch a humour in a man, as this mad
Merchant Matchil is poſſeſt with.
To marry ſo, to ſpight his childe and kindred.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has made his daughter by't a match worth nothing.
And there your hope is gone.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And yours in me.
For as I ſaid before, good Valentine.
I muſt returne you to your City wives.
By the old trade to pick your maintenance
Out of em, as you boaſt you can.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well, ſir.
And now to let you know that I can live
Without the helps of ſuch cool friends as you.
I'le ſhew you a preſent probability.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doeſt ſee yond pretty mumping peece i'th' ſhop there?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, is that one—?

sp.speaker: Val
sp.l: One o'th' fourty, boy,
That renders tribute in to my Exchecquer.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Didſt ever lie with her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How plain you are. Not I, not I.
That▪s her fool-husbands word.
Let it ſuſſice that I have ſeen her thrice.
And that I lay with, drink, and weare her money.
O 'tis the ſweeteſt Rogue.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: How got you acquainted.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le tell you that, walking by chance as now,
Before her ſhop, where a young Gentleman
Was bargaining, he call'd me by my name,

sp.speaker: Val Askall.
sp.l: Inſtantly her eye was fixt,
And ſtreight ran over my delineaments,
Which I ſet to her view; and took occaſion
To ask her how the object pleaſ'd her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Bold-face.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I never loſt by that.
She then demands, Is your name Askall, ſir?
I anſwer, Yes. Pray of what countrey, ſir?
I told her; when a ſudden flaming bluſh
Did in her face betray the fire of love,
That was at th' inſtant raging in her breaſt,
She look't me through and through. Sigh'd, turn'd away.
Then look't again under her hat-brims thus.
And thus I nimbly catch't her with mine eye.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I, thou haſt a devilliſh catch i'that ſame eye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, what I have, I have. I gave a leere
With that ſame eye that made her turne her whitesup.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But to the point.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why do you think a woman's ſo quickly brought to th' point?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: VVhat follow'd then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſaw ſhe was ſtruck, and thus I gave her line
To play withal. I whiſper'd in her eare,
The way to finde my lodging and my ſervice.
Next morning early comes a meſſage to me,
Inviting me to dinner: Chear and welcome
Plenteouſly flowed; and ſir, before we parted
Upon ſome private conference, twenty pieces
Were clutch't into this hand, but with a caution
To be diſcreet and thrifty of her purſe,
And keep a friend in ſtore. I have been modeſt,
And have not ſtruck her ſince, but for ten more.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And that's your laſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I le hold you ten o that
See ſhe has ſpied me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: VVhat lack ye, Gentlemen; faire cut-work bands, boot-hooſe, or boot-hooſe tops, ſhirts, waſt-coats, night-caps, what will you buy?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I come not now to buy.
But in plain termes to borrow. Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not on theſe termes.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sure thou miſtak'ſt the woman.
This is not ſhe, thou talk'ſt fo freely on Bounce.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: She's cautious before thee. Walk off a little.
Now you may hear me, Lady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Give me leave
A little, firſt to wonder at your raſhneſſe,
To talk ſo openly before a ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My intimate friend: I'le truſt him with my life.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What's that to my unblemiſh't reputation?
'Tis not your life can ſalve that, being wounded.
But thus it is, when women out of goodneſſe
Hazard their fortunes to relieve the wants
Of ſuch as you, that carry no reſpect,
But to your own licentious Appetites.
And think no favour's ſweet, unleſſe you may
Have priviledge to boaſt 'hem to our ſhame.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I do not boaſt of yours.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Pray, boaſt no more
Then you have found, and much good may they do you.
'Tis not poor thirty pieces can undo me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, nor ten more I hope; and that's the ſumme
I would entreat: all makes but fourty pound.
I'll pay thee like a Gentleman, as I am one,
Either in money; or doeſt hear me, Rogue,
In what ſhall pleaſe thee better. Come, be wiſe,
Thy husband's a dull ducking Gameſter. And
Kennels his water-dog in Turnbull-ſtreet.
We'll anſwer his delights with better ſport.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: There's your preſumption.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, 'tis my ambition.
When ſhall we walk to Totnam? or croſſe o're
The water, or take Coach to Kengington
Or Padington; or to ſome one or other
O'th' City out-leaps for an afternoon,
And hear the Cuckow ſing to th' purpoſe? when?

sp.speaker: Had.
sp.l: A woman were a wiſe one that would truſt
Her ſelfe in ſuch wilde hands as yours; to have
Her name made Tavern-talk among your blade,
And thruſt i'th 'liſt of your looſe-hilted Myſtreſſes:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O no; fie no: you cannot think how cloſe
And careful I will be. Heark in thine eare.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cannot blame this fellow now ſo much
For uſing of his wits to get his living,
Though in an idle way; as for traducing
People of worth and vertue, as this woman
Who I am credibly inform'd is vertuous
And too diſcreet for him to ſhark upon.
Therefore to grace himſelf, he ſlanders her.
I have alwayes lik't his company till now,
And ſhall hereafter be more wary of him.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Well ſir, upon pour faithful proteſtation,
And vow of ſecreſie, liere's ten pieces more.
You have found a tender-hearted woman of me
Over your wants; and all the ſatisfaction
That I deſire, is, that I may not ſuffer
Under a laviſh tongue; 'tis eaſie payment.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, but I'le pay thee better. Therefore tell me, when we ſhall meet and have a ſpirta|broad.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Your friend ſtayes for you, ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh, let him ſtay.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: You ſlight him now, but he knows all your Councels.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By this good tongue, no more then the un|begotten Hans that I mean to clap into thy Kel|der.
sp.l: Nor ever ſhall: doeſt think I am ſo fooliſh
To talk away my hopes? No, thou art my Faery,
Pinch me to death when I diſcover thee.

sp.speaker: Han,
sp.l: Go to, avoid ſuſpition then, beſides
I have occaſions that do call me hence.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Your ſtay was ſomewhat long.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet 'twas to purpoſe.
As here you may behold, but I muſt make no words on't.
She has enjoyn'd me that. O'tis a cunning Gypſie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: So't ſeems, by truſting thee that haſt no pow|er to keep a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, to tell you true.
My conſcience will not beare't, I cannot be
So ungrateful to receive a courteſie,
But to acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yet thou haſt the conſcience
To work a mans eſtate out of his hands
By his wives frailty, even to break his back.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis rather to be fear'd ſhe may break mine.
She's a tight ſtrong dock't Tit.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O Tradeſmen, why do you marry?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why? to make Tradeſwomen.
For Gentlemen that want money and commodity.
You know the thing that I call father in 〈◊〉,
That had my mothers whole eſtate, and butied her,
Allowes me nothing.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thank your own ſweet courſes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My courſes are ſweet courſes, they ſerve me to live upon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But I ſhall put you off
O'one of your ſweet courſes, or at leaſt
I'le ſtrain a point of friendſhip to be ſatisfied
Touching this woman, 'twill be worth diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But why theſe cloudy looks? do not you like my courſes? ha▪

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I cry thee mercy, Val.
I was upon our former ſubject Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I there's a haſty match clap't up. You ask't
Why Tradeſmen marry, there's a marriage now!
A humorous Coxſcombe that could never laugh
In all his laſt wives dayes; and ſince her death
Could ne're be ſad. For him to marry his Malkin
For poor and courſe obedience. Well. I hope
To take my courſe in his houſe yet for all.
Her boaſted chaſtity and obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Wouldeſt thou touch ſuch a thing?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What, not for money?
She can pay well and her uglineſſe cannot fright me
I can do that work winking.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She can be no ſuch woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Tell not me
What any woman can or cannot be,
You'll give me leave to try my fortune with her,

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, and walk with you towards it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No newes, no tidings of 'em, Ephraim, ha!
Was even ſucg a ſcape?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Not ſince the Rape
Of H●llon● I'm perſwaded. I have ſearch't
With narrow eyes (as I may ſay) with care,
And diligence in moſt ſecret places.
And can no way inform my ſelf, what is
Betide of the young Damoſels, or old Squire.
Your Neece, and the French Virgin, and the man
Unworthy to be call'd your brother Strigood.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O hang him Villain.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Doubtleſſe 'twas his plot
To work upon your Ladiſhips good nature
To harbour them, that he might take th' advantage
Of ſtealing them away.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What to do, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: To do? much may be done by his ſeducements,
On two ſuch tender Virgins, though he ſhould
But plant them in our ſuburbs: but my feare
Is that he has tranſported them beyond ſeas
Into ſome Nunnery. Your Ladiſhip
Knows he is adverſe in Religion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know he is of none.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Satan will work.
The ſtronger in him, then to their ſubverſion.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How ſhall I anſwer now my brother Matchil?
But he is juſtly ſerv'd to marry ſo.
The thought of it torments me. Where's my comfort?
Where's Nehemiah, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: He's buſie, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What, at his book? or at his muſick, ha?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: That is, his Ballet, or his Jewes Trump. No,
Madam. He is buſie at his exerciſe of Armes
With a new Caſting top, a Cat and Catſtick,
I bought and brought him home.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I thank you for 'hem,
My careful diſcreet Ephraim. I like
His harmleſſe exerciſes well.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I hope,
Your Ladiſhip can ſay ſince I have had
The Government of him under your Ladiſhip,
I have been careful of the Gentleman,
And have his love withal ſo much, that I
Dare ſay (I hope you'll pardon the compariſon)
That had you married me (which was as likely
As that your brother would have ta'ne his Maid.
I think that Mr. Nehemiah would not
Have run away in hatred of our Match,
As Mrs. Joyce. it ſeems, hath done of theirs.
I hope your Ladiſhips pardon, I underſtand
My duty.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And you ſpeak but reaſon Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I have given her there a touch of my affection.
Who knowes how it may work?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go call him in.
I would not have him over heat himſelf.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: 'Tis a good care. And Madam, by the way,
Let me adviſe, that ſince his riper yeares
Require, and that faire Propoſitions
Of marriage are tender'd for him, that
We gently by degrees, do take him off
From childiſh exerciſe, indeed plaine boyes play.
More manly would become him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You would have him
Do worſe then, would you? and be nought, you var|let?
What! would you have him play at Mans-game, ha?
Fore he be married, ha! what, what! how now!
Is it but up and ride w'ye, ha!

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I humbly
Beſeech your Ladiſhips pardon, I will call
Sweet Mr. Nehemiah to your worſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Go, th'art an honeſt man. I know thou lov'ſt him.
Indeed he's all my comfort and my care
And I muſt naturally reſpect all thoſe
That do partake with me my care of him.
sp.stage: Enter Nehemiah, looking down and eating.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: my boy Negh, Sonne Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: F'ſooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That's my good Lamb. Hold up thy head; and thou.
Shalt have a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But mother f ſooth, when I have her,
Will ſhe play with me at peg-top?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: At any thing, my boy.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And ſhe ha' not good box and ſteel, I ſhall ſo grull her.
And then at Mumbledepeg I will ſo firk her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But when y'are married, you●ll finde other pa|ſtime.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Whate're I ſay, I have a meaning though.
But yet, I doubt, I ſhall not forſake all
My old fagaries in a yeare or two.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I know thy will is good to leave thy wag-tricks.
And I commend your underſtanding in it.
It ſhewes you man, and ready for a wife.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, f'ſooth, I think ſo; I Amardla.
For I did beat a boy as high as my ſelfe
Yeſterday, with one hand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where was thy tother.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: The boy had but one hand f'ſooth. I uſ'd both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well th'art too witty to live long, I feare.
But as I was ſaying, ſonne, I do expect
Sir Swithen Whimtby to bring his Neece.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Who f●ſooth, the crying Knight, he that has wept
E're ſince his Lady di'd; and mournes in colours;
Speaks nothing but in verſe, and gives me Ballats;
The old Knight Powel, that pronounces what dee call 'hem?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Odes childe and Elegies. He has been in|ſpir'd.
With the infection of Poetry,
E're ſince his wives departure: and 'tis thought
Nothing can put him out, or cure him of it
But a new wife to kill the furious itch of't,

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But is not his Neece too big for me? I would be loth
To be over-match'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O witty, witry, ſtill.
But when ſhe comes Nehemiah, What'll you ſay to her?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: I'll give her the time of the day or the night
I warrant her, come at what houre ſhe will.
Why if I eat not all before ſhe come.
(And ſhe muſt try her, if I do'nt) I'll ask her
If ſhe can ſpeak with plums in her mouth; and then
I'll offer her a long one and two round ones,
And nod at her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You will not, will you, ha?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, I know both what to ſay and do
I truſt I am not to be taught to wooe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Too witty ſtill, I ſay, to be long-liv'd.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: But heark you mother f'ſooth; I am told that you
Beare a moneths minde to that Sir Whimlby,
And a croſſe match is talk't on betwixt you
And the old Knight, and me and his young Neece.
O ho—is't ſo?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: This is no crafty childe.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Let me but ſee how you will handle him now
And mark how I'le come over her with ſmall Jerks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O th'art a witty wag. A bleſſing on it.
sp.stage: Enter Ephraim, uſhering Whimlby and Blith.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, Sir Swithen Whimlby and his Neece,
Mrs. Blith Tripſhort.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They are very welcome,
Noble Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Noble Mrs. Blith.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sweet Knight, y'are welcome.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Welcome, ſweet Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Still weeping.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: O good Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Still weeping for a husband.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother, ſhe puts me on't,
She laughes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Laugh with her then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Amardla, ſo I will, and if you laugh
At me, I'll laugh at you again, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Are you there with me? I'le be here with you then.
Will you eat any Sugar-plums? no, I'le eat 'em for you.
There's ha, ha, ha, ha, for you now.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Do you note, Sir Swithin, what a wag it is.
Walk into the next room Nehemiah. Did you note him?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Madam, to tell you true.
My love to you
Springs from the joy,
I take in your ſweet boy
sp.stage: —Eph. And that's the way to win her.
sp.l: I can take no delight
But in his ſight,
Nor any pride
Since my dear Griſſel di'd,
In all, I ſee on earth or finde in books,
But that which overcomes me in his lookes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O ſweet Sir Swithen, you have all woo'd and won me.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Then all my hopes are fruſtrate.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My ſonne ſhall have your Neece, and for mine own part.
You loving him ſo well, of what's in me.
I can deny you nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Gentle Madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: She offers up her ſelfe; now may the proverb
Of proffer'd ſervice light upon her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nay, Sir Swithen.
Let me entreat you to leave weeping now.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: When my dear Griſſel did.

l.hi: And when your Ladiſhip appears in ſight.
(Pardon) I cannot chuſe but cry out-right.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Alas, good Knight. He weeps pure Helicon.
He has not wherewithal to quench his love,
But his own teares. A wife would cool him better.
Why ſir, does ſight of me renew your grief?

sp.speaker: Whi.

l.hi: And till, to eaſe my paine,

sp.l: That in my Griſſel di'd.

l.hi: So oft as ſhe in you to me appears
My numbers cannot ceaſe to flow in tears.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Good ſir, collect your ſelf, and be aſſur'd
I am your own, ſo Neh. may have your Neece,
With her full Dowry of foure thouſand pounds.
My perſonal eſtate is full as much.
That and my ſelf are yours on the croſſe marriage,
You making me an anſwerable Joincture.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Is't come ſo near; I'le croſſe it, or my ſtar▪
Drop croſſes on my head. O vain, vain woman,
To doat on Poetry in an old man.
Ladies may love it in the young and bold,
And when they are ſick give gally-pots of gold,
For cordial Electuaries to chear
Their crop-ſick Muſes; but to an old and ſere
Man that out-lives his labours, who can be
So vain to give her ſelf away but ſhe.
I had been ſitter for her, and I'le watch
Occaſion yet, perhaps, to croſſe the match,
I can tu●n Poet too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dry now your eyes, and anſwer me in proſe,
Are you content to yield to thoſe conditions
I have propounded, ha!

sp.speaker: VVhim.
sp.l: I am content.
And now for joy could weep,
Finding my Griſſel in your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I hope the young ones do accord as well.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Proteſt, I cannot abide you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Nor I you.
Amardla, that I cannot.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: They'r agreed.
Madam, it ſeems they both are of one minde.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: I do not like it. What's the matter Nehemiah?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: She is no wife for me, ſhe has broke my Jewes-trump; look you here elſe. And almoſt broke my head with one of my bounding ſtones.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bleſſe my boy; ſhe has not, has ſhe, ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And yet after all that, and for all I offered to teach her to ſhoot in my Trunk and my Stone-bowe, do you think ſhe would play with me at Trou, Ma|dam? no, nor at any thing elſe. I'll none of her.
And yet I'le have her too. If ſhe will promiſe to do as I would have her hereafter.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There, do you note him there, Sir Swithen?
This childe has no childiſh meaning in't, I war|rant you.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: No Madam, no, I know him inwardly
He is my joy, and ſhe ſhall be conformable,
Or fare the worſe.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: She will, I know ſhe will.
Will you not have my ſon, ſweet Mrs. Blith?

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Sweet Madam, what to do? ha, ha, I ſhall be quickly weary with laughing at him. His fooling will ſoon be ſtale and ●edious; and then to beat him would be as toilſome to me; and laſtly, to be tied to nothing but to cuckold him, is ſuch a common Town-trick, that I ſcorne to follow the faſhion.

sp.speaker: La
sp.l: Can ſhe talk thus? ha!

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A merry harmleſſe Girle.
Fear not, good Madam, ſhe will come about.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: A thouſand mile about rather then meet him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I much deſire ſhe would; for now my ſonne
Is ſet a marrying, I warrant it pure thing
It is in paine, till it be at it: ha!
Pray bring her on, Sir Swithen, let him kiſſe her.
Poor heart, he licks his lips; and look how arſeward ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Fie Blith, be courteous, Blith.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother,—ſhe has ſpit Amard juſt in my mouth.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Amard, what's that? if you ſpeak French you wrong me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Gip, Mrs. Tripſhort. Is this the manners your Mother left you?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Speak not you of Mothers, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir ●w●then, will you ſ●e my childe abuſ'd ſo, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I can but grieve for't, Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: My mother is as good as your mother, ſo ſhe is, for all ſhe's dead.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I, well-ſaid Neh.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Yes, it appears in your good breeding
Your fine qualities expreſſe her vertues ſuſſiciently.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How dare you Huſwife talk thus to my ſon, of me, and before my face too? ha! Sir Swithen, can you think well of me, and ſuffer this, ha?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Alas, good Madam, I am down again I know not what to think of living woman now.

sp.speaker: La▪
sp.p: Do you bring your Neece to abuſe me?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: I am ſo drown'd in teares, that I cannot ●ee what to ſay to't.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, Amardla, the more I look on her, the better I like her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sayeſt ſo, my boy. Beſides, I have a conceit ſhe can out-ſcold you▪ and that's more then ever woman did, I think f'ſooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: For thee, I do forbear her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: By your leave, my Lady Neſtlecock, I have brought a ſiſter of yours here to ſalute you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Though unworthy to be of your Counſel, or at the Ceremony, I heard you were married brother. And by a Siſters name you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: I thank your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Sir Swithen Whimlby! and your pretty Neece! well met, what affairs have you in hand here? what do you cry for your old wife ſtill or for a new one? But heark, you Lady Siſter, where's my daugh|ter?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now for a tempeſt. Truly ſir, I know not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Is ſhenot with you, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: No truly, ſir.
She's ſlipt from me with her good Uncle Strigood.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: That Thief has ſold her then into ſome Baw|dihouſe
Was this your project for her education,
To ſteal my childe to make a whore of her?
Are you turn'd Lady b●ud now for your Neece
Becauſe you have no daughter? O the devil!
If there be Law, I'll trounce your Lady Hagſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: VVhat, what? how now? do you taunt me, ſirrah, ha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll make thee an example.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou haſt made thy ſelf an example, and the ſcorne of thine own childe in marrying of thy drudge there; and thats the cauſe of her running away thou mayeſt think, becauſe ſhe hates to live where ſhe muſt call her mother that was thy droile.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Droile, I think, ſhe ſaid.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Speak to her, I charge thee, on thy obedience to ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: The droile is now your brothers wife, Madam, and in that ſetting your Ladiſhips laviſh tongue aſide, as good a woman as your ſelfe, none diſpraiſ'd, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Well-ſaid Rachel, hold thine own Rachel. And ſo to you, ſir Sw then.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, come away, mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By and by, my boy.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.p: Do you preſume to call me drudge and droile, that am a Ladies Siſter every day in the week; and have been any time theſe three dayes, ha.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: That's not every day in a whole week yet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt not dare to call me ſiſter Huſ|wife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p:
Cods ſo, and why troe? becauſe a Lady ſcornes to be a huſwife, ha. If you be no huswife, I ſc●rn to call
you Siſter, I; though my husband be your brother. From whence came you troe, ha?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to the bold-face.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'ſooth come away, I am afear'd ſhe'l beat you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thanks, my good childe, but do not be afraid my Lamb.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Boldface, ha! Her brothers wife▪s a bold-face, but her face is not varniſh't over, yet like his Lady|ſiſters face, but it may be in time when ſhe learnes the trick on't, and have as many flies upon't, though not ſo troubled with 'hem, as a bald mare at Midſummer, hah.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to her, ſhe has charm'd the vertue of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I never heard her ſpeak ſo much in all her life, Sir Swithin, nor half ſo loud. hank heaven, ſhe has a voice yet on a good occaſion. And ſo farre I'll maintain her in it. Nephew Nehemiah, when ſaw you your Couſin Joyce.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O Lud, O mother f'ſooth, look you, mine Uncle holds me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Ah, naughty man, did a ſo gi▪me a ſtroke, and I'll beat it, ●h—.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Your wife has taught you to play the rude companion, has ſhe? Pray take her home ſir, and let her diſcipline your owne childe if you have one, and let mine alone. You know the way you came, ſir; or if you have a minde to ſtay here, Come Sir Swithen, come away children; I hope I ſhall finde ſome other room in mine own houſe, free from your aſſaults, if not, I'm ſure there's Law againſt Riots. Come Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Not yet good Madam Neſtlecock, you ſhall hear me.
You have entic'd away, then loſt my daughter.
And now y'are a jugling with your widow wit,
And your ſmall worme here, to catch up for Gudge|ons.
Sir Swithen and his Neece, I know your plot..
She's not fit match for you Sir Swithen; and her ſon
Much leſſe for your faire Neece. Come dry your eyes,
And look upon him, and not only look,
But laugh at him, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: I could now for him heartily.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Mark how his mothers milk drops at his noſe, while I ſhew you the mother and the childe.
He was her youngeſt ſonne, and all that's left of ſeven, and dreaming that he needs muſt prove a Prophet, ſhe has bred him up a fool.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: F'ſooth mother he mocks me, oh.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O prophane wretch, worſe then thy brother Strigood.
sp.l: Do not cry, Nehemiah, peace, good boy, peace. So ſo.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A tender mother I muſt ſay ſhe has been.
For till he was fifteen, none but her ſelfe
Muſt look his head, or waſh his pretty face
For making of it cry. Laugh at her good Sir Swithen.
And before that, till he was twelve yeares old
She would dance him on her knee, and play with's Cock.

sp.speaker: Wh●m.
sp.l: Ah ah ah ah.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: So well-ſaid, Sir Swithen.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Juſt ſo efac my mother would ſerve me, ha, ha.
Is not this better then whining.
Yes, or perhaps then wiving either.

sp.speaker: Rac.
sp.l: Do you ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p:
Well ſaid, Sir Swithen, laugh on. I hope I ha' done a cure on him, by ſhewing him a
more ridiculous object then himſelfe, to turne the tide of's tears.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.l: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Laugh ſtill, defie the fiends, women, and all their works.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, let the dead go, and the quick care for themſelves. You buri'd your wife, and cri'd, and I buried mine.
sp.l: And laugh; which is the manlier Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He knows not that he is married agen.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: You are the merrieſt Merchant, ha, ha, ha.
I think I ſhall not marry again in haſte, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well-ſaid, hold there. And for your Neece
Let me alone. I'le fit her with a match.
I know a Lad that's worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He●ll laugh too much, I feare.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He may at you,
For your officiouſneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: To thruſt your ſelf into unthankful offices.
In things concerne you not. Will you turne Matchmaker
For others un-intreated, 'tis enough.
For you, I hope, that you have match't your ſelfe, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hah! Do you hab, or talk to me?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Who elſe
Should talk or give you counſel but your wife?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: VVell-ſaid Rachel, hold thine own Rachel.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am match't again.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pax, cry again, or burſt thy ſelf with laugh|ing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: La. Ha, ha, ha. Laugh ſon Nehemiah.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Ha, ha. ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What am I? what do you make of me?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, what ha' you made your ſelf? beſt ask the Chimney piece that you have married there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Durſt thou advance a voice againſt me, ha?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You did commend it in me againſt your Si|ſter.
And I may better be familiar with you;
Hah, are you not my husband? I am ſure
'Tis not ſo long ſince we were married, that
You can forget it, or ●epent ſo ſoon.
I am not now your ſlave, to have my face
Waſh't with your ſnuffes, nor to be kick't and trod on
VVithout reſiſtance, nor to make you anſwers
Meerly with ſilent court'ſies, run when you bid go
To fetch and carry like your Spaniel,
In which condition I liv●d long enough,
And was content until ●ou freed me out on't.
Now free I am, and will be a free woman,
As you are a free-man, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O baſe-borne begger.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You wrong your wife in that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How ſhe holds up the wife.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I never beg'd
Nor mov'd a lip to be your wife, not I,
You held my ſervice portion good enough,
And for my blood 'tis no more baſe then yours,
Since both are mixt in marriage.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Come your way.
And let me hear you ſpeak ſo much at home.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I hope I may be bolder in mine own houſe.
So Madam, for the love I have found in yours,
You ſhall be welcome thither, when y' are ſent for.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What a bold piece of Kitchin-ſtuffe is this?
Brothery' are match't.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: And catch't ifacla, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He has not a word to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Follow me home and durſt.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I dare without more leave taking, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Was ever combe ſo cut.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: There's a new Aunt indeed! ſhe brought me nothing.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: I have not laught ſo much I know not when,
H'has made me laugh until I cry agen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Again, you are welcom, Sir, Mrs. Blith
Now the unwelcome gueſts are gone, lets in
And dine, then will we after meat

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Of Joinctures, Madam, and of Nuptials treat.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Right ſir.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Love, as I ſhall adore thee for a deity.
Rid me of this ridiculous ſociety.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Matchil, Rachel, between Eraſmus and Valentine.

sp.speaker: Eraſ.
sp.p: GOod Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Myſtris, be not ſo violent.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'll rather run my Countrey, Gentlemen, then endure her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You were beſt to kill her then, and then you'll have no other courſe to take, unleſſe you ſtay and be|hang'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I'le make thee glad to flie firſt.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: From my houſe and husband ſhall I? from my poſſeſſions ſhall I? And leave you all to ſpend in riot ſhall I? No ſir, I'le ſtay and ſpend my ſhare if you go to that, that will I. And make all flie as well as you, and you go to that, that will I, ha.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Whoop, whow.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Nay, fle be not ſo loud.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: What didſt thou bring thou drudge thou.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That which you were content to drudge withal, I am too ſure o' that. The drudge you ſpeak of is no worſe then your own wife, I am too ſure o'that.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Did you not fay for better, for worſe? And if 'twere worſe then 'tis, 'twere all too good for you. And that I hope I ſhall finde ſome good Friend to know.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That I like well, I'le be her firſt man.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I truſt you have found the drudge to be a woman fit to content a man, and if you grant not that, ſome better man perhaps ſhall be a Judge, betwixt you and the drudge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She threatens hornes. I think.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hornes. I think, you ſaid. If 'twere ſo 'twere too good for you. Cannot your own wife content you, ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She holds up that point ſtoutly.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That ſhall be tri'd.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: O for an expert Chyrurgion now to caſt her in a dead ſleep, and geld her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Introth you will be both ſorry, when your paſſion gives but leaſt way to your underſtandings. Mr. Matchil, let me perſwade with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Never unieſſe you bring her on her knees, to crave forgiveneſſe at my foot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If you but yield an inch he treads upon your neck, I will not give an under ſpur-leather for you. But bear it out bravely, and I'll be your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Mrs. Match-ill indeed, to be ſo match't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So match't▪ how match't? what from the hur|den ſinock with lockram upper-bodies, and hempen ſheets, to weare and ſleep in Holland, and from the dripping-pan to eat in ſilver, ●ha. Do you repine at your Match, ha. Is wealth contemptible to you?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I was better content in my povertie. I have not been my ſelfe, Gentlemen, ſince he marri|ed me.

sp.speaker: Mas.
sp.p: You may be poor again as ſoon as you pleaſe, the door is open, depart at your pleaſure; you know the way to your old Aunt the Apple-woman, at Hock|ly-hole. Take your knitting Needles again, and live with her, go.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No ſir, I'll ſtay with you, and make you as poor before I have done wi' ye, as I was before you had me Gent. I ſhall not be my ſelf till then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: The devil you ſhall. Was ever ſuch a crook|ed condition crept into a thing like woman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet this ſir, is the rare piece of obedience
You boaſted of, and ſaid you would defie
The devil to diſhoneſt her, I am ſorry
Your judgement led you into ſuch an errour,
Already ſhe's my Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, and I●le call him ſervant, Gentlewomen uſe it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do ſo, Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If ſhe, ſir, be your Myſtreſſe, Then am I
Your Maſter-in-law, out of my houſe I charge you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Doeſt thou conſpire to grieve him?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Troth, ſir, I did but jeſt. You have my pity.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: All are not times for Jeſt, friend Valentine.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.p: O my affliction!

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: Have a little patience, ſir.
sp.l: While I talk calmly with her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Leave me then
A while unto my thoughts. Go into the houſe.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray ſervant help me here a little. Do ſo much
As winde up my Jack for me, my Watch I would ſay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her Jack▪ ſhe's in the Kitchin ſtill.
A pretty Watch this, Myſtreſſe, what did you pay for't.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nothing, my husband ga't me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pity the Spring is broke, but I can get it mended.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Good ſervant take it with you then to the Jack-makers, I would ſay, the Watch-makers. Come Gentlemen, ſhall we have a craſh at cards?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.p: With all my heart. What is your game?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can play a many old games. One and thirty bone-ace, Tickle me quicklie, and my Ladies hole, and ſichie. But you ſhall teach me new ones, though I loſe money for my learning, Gleek and Primero, Greſco ſaut, primofiſtula, I know all by hear-ſay. Come let us have a bout at ſomewhat. I have money e|nough.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And I'le make ſhift to eaſe you of ſome on't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Affliction on affliction hourely findes me,
And layes me on the Rack, tearing my heart
Like greedie vultures, O my heart, this heart
That I ſo long ſuppoſ'd impenetrable
By all the darts of ſorrow, is now transfixt,
Shot through and through with torments, and by this.
This laſt made ſenſible of all the reſt.
My ſons untimely death, my daughters loſſe.
My Siſters follies, and my Brothers vices.
My ſervants falſhood, and the jeers of ſtrangers
Now wound me all at once; and all through this
Predominant blow, pull'd on me by mine own
Impetuous raſhneſſe. Let me here conſider,
While my hearts torture keeps my ſoule awake,
The moving cauſe of all theſe ill effects.
Mine own unbridled wilde affections.
Scorne of example, and contempt of counſel.
I cannot but obſerve withal, how juſt,
A judgement follows mine own wilful acts,
In the ſame kinde of doing ills for ills.
For my loſt ſonne, I raſhly wrought revenge
Upon an innocent Girle; and with her
Have loſt mine own; and for th'unmanly joy
I took in one wives death, becauſe a Shrew.
(Though otherwiſe vertuous) I am in another
Trebly tormented; not alone with noiſe,
But with a feare of unchaſte purpoſes,
Which if they come to act, my purſe muſt pay for.
I ſee my faults, and feel the puniſhments.
And rather then ſtand out in my defence
T'enjoy ſome peace, I will endure ſome ſorrow
And beare it civilly. Within there.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Go call your Myſtreſſe, pray her to come a|lone.
My reſolution brings me yet ſome eaſe:
Men that are borne to ſerve, muſt ſeek to pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Rachel.

sp.speaker: Ra
sp.l: Your pleaſure quickly, I have left
My company, my ſervant, and my friend yond,
Sawing againſt one another at Corne the Caſter; till I come to 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And then all three to In and In, is't ſo?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My ſervant, and my friend and I are e'ne all one.
They are the goodeſt Gentlemen, the beſt com|pany.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your ſervant and your friend.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes, and my ſervant playes for me now in my abſence, as farre as ten pieces go that I left him. My plow goes there, though I am here.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your plow makes vile baulkes of my money the while.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am not ſo ill a huswife as you imagine. And my friend, and my ſervant have promiſ'd to carry me abroad, to this town, and to that town, and tother town, and whow, I know not whither. And my ſer|vant will have me to Hide-Park he ſayes, to ſee and to ſhew all, as well as the brave Gallants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is gallant indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And my friend will carry me to a whatdeecall, a new Academy, where I ſhall ſee the rareſt muſick and dancing, he ſayes, and learn the fineſt Complements. and other courtly qualities that are to be had for mo|ney, and ſuch inſtructions for the neweſt faſhions

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: She will flie to the devil for faſhions ſake. Pray ſtay a little, and let me talk calmely with you. You have almoſt broke my heart.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But not altogether, I hope. I would not win ſo great a game, without ſome ſport in playing it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear me.
I know you put on this affected carriage,
But to try maſterie, and the diſeaſe
Being ſo general among all women,
Is in you therefore more excuſable.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O, are you coming?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Hear what I will ſay to you.
And finde in that a husbands good affection.
I love my peace, and would preſerve my honour,
Both which are in your breaſts to ſave or ſpoil.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And can you think the way to purchaſe peace
Is by a war with me? hah, you are cozen'd.
Do you think your domineering looks, or noiſe,
Or blowes, can fright me into quietneſſe,
Or that you ſhall have honour by abaſing
Your wife?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You will not underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Hah.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Though I love peace, and would preſerve my honour.
I'le yield in both to you, and can, (I have been
So uſ●d to thraldome) But the world, the world
Is ſuch a Talker.—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I have found the man.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There I would ſave a reputation.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: He's loth to bring it out; I'le cloſe w'ye.
You'll be content ſo, I will ſuffer you
To bear a loud command o're me in publick,
That I ſhall carrie it in private. Is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Truly wife, yes.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: You'll give me leave to beat you
In private then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Nay, we'll bar blowes at all times.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: But if I chance to give you a rap or two,
Or now and then a nip, and you ſtrike me
Again, I'le ſtrike you ſome way elſe, as you
Would not be ſtruck. And ſo obſerve my carriage.
The Gentlemen are coming.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: O, here they are.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And not by the eares: that's wonderful.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Sir, I perceive my errour, and repent it.
Promiſing you in all my after life,
To be a faithful and obedient wife.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He has fetch't her about, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Grammercy Rachel, binde it with a kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And thus it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Gentlemen, have ye found us?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: With joy to ſee this reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thus ſhall ye ſee it ever, Gentlemen.
I knew ſhe would yield, or I ſhould make her heart ake.
What were a husband, if he were not Maſter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have wonne the ſield, it ſeems, yet I may hope
I have not loſt a Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor I a friend.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In a faire way, Gentlemen, I ſhall
Abridge her of no courtly priviledge.
But no more haytie twaytie tricks, I charge you.
She ſhall not jaunt to this nor that town with you.
(I thank you for your care) nor to Hide-Park.
Nor to the Academy you tell her of, without my leave.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And do you ſay ſo Myſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Truly yes.
I am no ſuch woman as you took me for,
With Mr. Matchils leave you may be welcome
Home to his houſe in good and ſeemly ſort.
Put pray expect no further entertainment
Then he ſhall well allow of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I have loſt her.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: This change is admirable.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Why do you admire it.
Is ſhe not mine? how could you think ſhe durſt
Stand out in her rebellion? although the devil
Who ſoothes all Upſtarts diſpoſitions
Into an over-weening of themſelves.
Poſſeſt her for a time, had not I power
And vertue do you think to conjure him out?
What have I ſtudied for, think you, e're ſince
My laſt wife di'd, but how to rule the next?
Go get you in, there's ſomething in the houſe
Worth looking after.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I be ſworn, he frights her.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Would I had you within to perform covenants.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What do you grow rebellious again.
Why ſtir you not elſe, ha? prithee Sweetheart
Reſpect my dignity, or only ſeem to do it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Yes, I will only ſeem to do it.
