sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He makes her tremble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I muſt about my houſe-●ffaires.
So, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er. Val.
sp.l: Good Mrs. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Aha.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: And Mr. Matchil, at your own good pleaſure.
Having in private ſomething to impart to you,
I would entreat your preſence.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Your eare before I go good Mr. Matchil.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: H'has brought her to her ſervile old obedi|ence.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O—oh.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: That is a private touch, ſir, of the buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Pox of your Lobſter claws. There waanip▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: It will be worth conſideration, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Well, Ile come to you preſently.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Any ill newes that you change colour ſo?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No, nothing, nothing but a womaniſh feare.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well, you are a happy man that have o' recom her.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: You know not me yet Gentlemen, I know a word in private would do it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yet ſhe deſires to have you again in pri|vate.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis her abundant love, and pure obedience.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: She comes again.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Since y'are not yet diſpoſ'd to cnter, ſir.
One word more, Mr. Matchil, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Oh,—I underſtand you. Go, I'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Again, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I muſt weare Lantern-hornes upon mine arms,
If ſhe uſe this. Well, Gentlemen, at your own time
Lets ſee yee. My Rach. ſhall make you welcome,
And for me, you know me, I will ſtill be Maſter.—
I come, I come, I come. So, farewel Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha, do you run?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: What doeſt thou think of this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le lay all the tricks I have againſt his brags.
She maſters him in private, and that all
This ſhew of her obedience is diſſembled.
My hope revives again; we muſt abroad with her.
But tell me, what new Academy's that
You told her of, I underſtand not that yet.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nor have I ſeen it, but we both will ſhortlie.
'Tis but of two or three dayes ſtanding yet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Where is it? who are the Profeſſours,
And what the Arts?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I'le tell thee all know.
It carries a love-ſound; but I am told
It is but private lodgings kept by
Both men and women, as I am inform'd, after the French manner.
That profeſſe Muſick, Dancing, Faſhion, Comple|ment.—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And no drabbing?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: A little perhaps in private.
But gueſſe now in whoſe houſe all this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Even in your City-Myſtreſſes, that lends you
Money ſo freely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Who Camelion?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I doubt, your borrowing of the wife
Has broke the husband, put'hem off their trade,
And now they ſeek new wayes to live by projects.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And could you keep this from me all this while,
Till I am there, each ſtep's a tedious mile.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But not without me, good Val. We'll finde a time.
Together, and our Mrs. Matchil with us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Cock, I proteſt Cock, I commend thy courſe
Thou haſt taken in brave Lodgers, gallant Gueſts,
Gueſts o'th' Game Cock; and my houſe is counted
A houſe of quality and recreation, Cock,
In civil ſort and gentle faſhion, Cock,
Sbobs Cock, I know thou wouldeſt not have it other|wiſe
For all the wealth i'th' Exchange.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But Rafe you care not
What people ſay, ſo I bring you in profit.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, not I, my little Cockſie Nanſie,
Not I, piſh, Hony ſoit qui maly penſe.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Some do not ſtick to ſay, I know what's what,
And that our houſe is no better then it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh, Hony ſoit agen, i'th' very teeth of 'hem,
Let 'hem all ſay what they will. Dainty come thou to me.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But I know what I know, and that our houſe is
Better then it ſhould be, if ſome of them
Had but the keeping of it, that ſpeak ſo ill on't.
And that the Gentlewomen in our houſe
Are well-condition'd, and as chaſte as courteous.
And if you ſaw, (as they deſire I ſhould
See all betwixt their great Reſorts and them)
You'd be in love with their ſweet way of living.
Then for their dancing, 'tis ſo neat and graceful.
See 'hem anon at practice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, Cock, I'le ſee nothing.
I will not leave one ducking pond, for ten dancing ſchooles.
Yet I can dance, and love it: you know that Cock.
And though you are a Gentlewoman borne,
You took me for my legs, not ●or my armes.
Is not that a good Jeſt, Cock. Sbobs 'twas out before
I was aware. Here comes their father.
sp.stage: Enter Strigood, Caſh, diſguiz'd in bravery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It ſeems he has brought in ſome new ſcholar.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Where are my daughters, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Cloſe in their chamber, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Are none of our Academicks come yet?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Not any, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I look for ſome anon
Pray bid the Girles come down
To practiſe.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Sir, when I was a Batchelour, I practiſ'd,
Dauncing ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Indeed, good Landlord?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And maugre wedloek, I have ſomething left
Yet in theſe legs, that can expreſſe at leaſt
Love to the quality.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: That ſhall not be loſt,
If I can further it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I ſaw laſt night
Your new French daunce of three, what call you it?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I think I could make one in't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: This Gentleman's another, call the Muſick.
I'le try what you can do.
Caſh, Thou art welcom, I am glad I met thee.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: But that you had foreknowledge of my habit,
And ſeen it in my out-leaps, as you call 'hem,
I might ha' paſt. But you in this diſguiſe,
None but the devil himſelf that is your Inmate,
And lodges with you in it, could have known you.
Sure he deviſ'd it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: No, you are ſhort.
I learn't it of a Jeſuite.
And 'twas but eaſie: ſhaving of my old
Gray haire and beard off; clapping on this perrule
After the faſhion; having but few wrinkles.
(For which I thank my Batchelourſhip, I paſſe
For a brisk youth. But for my Hannibal eye here. And by my brothers
Courteous advice I have ta'ne a courſe to live
Vpon my ſtock of wit, ſlight and activity,
With nimble braine, quick hands, and aery heels, as he told me, ha!

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: He could not think you would have ſtolne his daughter to ha' ſet up withal.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: But now I care not
What the wretch thinks, ſo he diſcovers nothing,
I dare truſt thee Caſh, partly on thy Oath
Which I have ta'ne you know: but more reſpectively
Upon your fourty pieces here, friend Caſh,
Which I have alſo ta'ne: but moſt of all
For that I know you dare not make diſcovery,
For feare of Little-eaſe. That were a priſon
Too fearful for ſuch bravery to ſtoop into.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: That keeps me ſtill in awe. 'Tis well you know it.
But it is better, he has no ſuſpition
That I am run away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Muſick's ready, ſir.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Play then,—the Tresboun.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Twas very well done, Landlord, I proteſt
I love your houſe the better for your quality.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But if you ſaw me at the ducking pond,
Me and my Trull.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Your Trull?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I mean, my bitch, ſir.
O ſhe would raviſh you.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Some other time.
Here comes your wife. The newes good Landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Newes out of France, your fame is ſpread a|broad.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: How out of France?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Two young French Gentlemen.
New come aſhore, the daintieſt ſweeteſt Gentlemen
That e're I ſaw (now you'll be jealous Rafe)

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Are come to lodge here, having heard
It ſeems, that you profeſſe French qualities.
And inſtantly deſire to be acquainted
With you and your ſweet company.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can they ſpeak Engliſh?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: One very well: and the tother can ſay
Tree Franſh crown for two Engliſh kiſſe already,
Now be jealous Rafe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh, Hony ſoit qui maly penſe.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You can ſpeak French, Landlord.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: So much as you have heard, not one word more.
I aſſure you but this, Adieu Monſieur and ſo
I leave you.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will you not ſee the Gallants Rafe?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not I, I wo'nt be jealous Cock, and ſo▪
By the Back-door to the ducking pond. I go.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enter then Landlady, where be theſe Girles?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here they are come.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Stand aſide Caſh, and be not yet diſcovered.
Now Ladies, how do y'like your way of living?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I do not like it Uncle.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Troth, nor I ſir.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: We eat and lodge well; and we weare good cloathes.
And keep our credit in the houſe we live in,
But what we ſuffer in our reputation
Abroad, is dangerouſly doubtful.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Here we are view'd and review'd by all com|ers.
Courted and tempted too, and though w'are ſafe
In our chaſte thoughts, the impious world may ſay,
We are ſet out to common ſale.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: So, ſo.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And ſo you are to th' utmoſt of his power
I dare be ſworue;

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But Uncle, for the time that you intend
To ſtay, I pray admit no new acquaintance,
Nor any more, leſt I for my eſcape
Venture a leap two ſtories deep.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha! you ſaid?
You know I have diſcloſ'd you to no eye
That could take knowledge who or whence you are,
And for the forrein ſtrangers, and ſuch Townsfolks
As knew us not; what need we weigh their thoughts.
Their gold is weight; let that be all we look to.
While our deſerving arts and qualities
Require it from 'hem. If they think us wicked,
And hope to get Virginities for ſalary,
And pay for their deluded hopes before-hand.
What is our act bnt Juſtice on their follies,
In taking of their prodigal coine?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I hope,
You deal not that way for us.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Never fear it.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But Uncle, though you have taught us courtly
Gypſie tricks.
That ſomewhat trench upon our modeſties.
Pray let it not be thought we'll ſell our honeſties.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Truſt to my care.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And thats the way to do it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And in that care be confidently ſeen,
By a deſerving Gentleman, whom I
Preſent to kiſſe your hands.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I will ſee none.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You need not feare me, Lady; for I can
But tell your father, if you ſlight his ſervant.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Bleſſe us! what Metamorphoſis is this?
'Tis Caſh your fathers man.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Is this the habit of a Merchants Prentice?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Is this the lodging of a Merchants daugh|ter?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Has his great marriage turn'd my fathers houſe
Into a ſumptuous Palace, that he keeps
Such coſtly men. Or doth the bravery
Of his late beauteous Bride require ſuch gorgeous
Attendants? Pray what office may you fill
About her perſon.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Will you home and ſee?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: We are betray'd?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Be not afraid of Caſh.
I know him, and he knows us. He is our friend
And we'll be his. As for his bravery
'Tis no new thing with him. I know him of old.
This ſute's his worſt of foure.
And he's one
Of the foure famous Prentices o'th' time.
None of the Cream and Cake-boyes, nor of thoſe,
That gall their hands with ſtool-balls, or their Cat|ſticks,
For white-pots, pudding-pies, ſtew'd prunes, and Tanſies.
To feaſt their Titts at Iſlington or Hogſden.
But haunts the famous Ordinaries o'th' time,
Where the beſt chear, beſt game, beſt company are fre|quent.
Lords call him Couſin at the Bowling Green; And the great Tennis-Court.
Thy fathers money
Would ruſt elſe, Girle. Keep thou our Councel Caſh.
And we'll keep thine, though't be to the undoing
Of him and all the wretches of his brotherhood,
That love their money, and their baſe deſires,
Better then blood or name.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: But can you hold
It good in any ſervant ſo to hazard
His Maſters livelihood.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Can you hold your peace?
He's wiſe, and ſaves by't all this while: He knows
His friends are bound in full two thouſand pounds,
For's truth, and his true ſervice, and perhaps,
He is not out above one thouſand yet,
Where's your wit now?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Myſtreſſe, I'le do you ſervice, and be true to you.
I'd not have miſt of this diſcovery.—

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You ſee ſhe hearkens to him. Talk aſide Caſh.
And touch her boldly.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I would not have miſt it.
For all the wealth your father has: and at
Convenient privacy. Ple give you reaſons,
That ſhall gaine your belief to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: The French Gallants.
I had almoſt forgot them. They are a paire
Of delicate young Monſieurs. If they have
But crownes enough, they are the likelicſt
Merchants for my new Mart that I can chooſe.
She ſaid they can ſpeak Engliſh, that's a help.
For devil of French have I to entertain 'hem.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: See mine own heart, here's more temptation ſtill.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I'le not endure the onſet.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I le defend you.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Yet there are graces in their looks methinks,
That do invite my ſtay.

l.hi: N' entendes vous, la langue francois Mon|ſieur dittez.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I would be glad to heare you ſpeak the lan|guage
I better underſtand, and that is Engliſh.
In which you are moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Your faire courteſie
Merits our greateſt thanks.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: I tanck you, ſir.
I have bid Fraunce adieu to come and learn
De Engliſh very well; I ſpeak a lietel,
But de Engliſh Meſtereſſe can teach de beſt.
I ſhall be glad to take my commencements,
Or my firſt Leſſons from theſe Ladies lips.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: A fine forward ſpark?

sp.speaker: Gali
sp.l: O ſweet, O delicate.
Ladies, if you will breath into me Engliſh,
I ſhall, if you pleaſe, put Franſh into you.
Ʋne pour l'antre, dat is one for anoder.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: So they might make a hot bargain on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Are theſe your Civil Gentlemen, Landlady?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: He ſeems a little waggiſh: but the other
Is wondrous civil. He comes bluſhingly.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: You are before me in the Salutation
Of theſe faire Ladies, Monſieur Galiard:

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Il E'vray Monſieur Papilion, I kiſſe before, then you moſe kiſſe behind.
But let me pray my tardineſſe be excuſ'd

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: You pronounce Engliſh well ſir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I am glad
You like it Lady.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I like the others as well.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I have before ſpent many monethes in Eng|land:
And my great love unto the Nation,
Eſpecially to the beauties of your Sexe,
Retracts me hither, where my friend was never.
Till now that my perfwaſion wonne his company;
And happily, I ſuppoſe, we are arriv'd:
That, to the ſight and knowledge we have had
Of Muſick, Daunces, Courtſhips, and Behaviour.
Through all parts of our Countrey, France, with an
Addition of all Italy affords.
Where (by all beſt opinions) even the choiceſt
Of ſuch court qualities, and active graces,
Have had their Spring, we now, as Fame ſuggeſts,
Shall in this faire Society, diſcerne
More then by all our former obſervation.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Report, ſir, ſpeaks too loud on our behalfe,
And let me pray ye, that it not beget
Too great an expectation on our weakneſſe,
By your too gentle ſuffrage. What we can,
We'll do.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: O wee dats de beſt. Doe is de ting
De Franſh man loves: If all your both two daugh|ters
Shew all; all makes but more deſire to do.
Speak I no good Engliſh, Madamoiſelle?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: You no underſtand me,
Becauſe you tinck I lie. But if you lie
With me, I make you underſtand me preſently.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: This hot-rein'd Mouſieur takes 'em for the ſame.
Strigood would have 'em be I came in time.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: At afternoon we'll have an exerciſe
Of courtſhip, Gentlemen. In the Interim,
If you will have to ſtir the appetite,
A dance before our Ordinary we are for you.

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: And we for you Alloun al Egremant Alloun

l.hi: Monſieur Papillion pour l' honour de France.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: VVhat are your dances chiefly in requeſt.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Good Landlady, bid the Muſick be in r●adineſſe.
And then ſee dinner ſet upon the table.
We have Sir for Corants,—La Miniard,

l.hi: La Vemimde, Le Marqueſſe, Le Holland,
La Brittaine, Le Roy, Le Prince, Le Montague,

sp.l: The Saraband; the Canaries, La Reverree.
For Galliards, the Sellibrand, the Dolphine,
The new Galliard, the Valette Galliard and lepees,

sp.speaker: Gali.
sp.l: 'Tis all very good Monſieur Papillica Eſſontes

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And heark you, Monſieur Strigood, you will be put to't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I feare no French flaſhes. Beare up Caſh. If we cannot daunce 'hem of o' their legs, our wenches can,
I warrant thee. Muſick be ready.
Gallants, what are you pleaſed to daunce?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: tells what, &c.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Gentlemen, your dinner ſtays meat will be cold.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: And we are hot, 'tis better that take cold then we.
But come, one table for us all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stri. Agreed, agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I ſay ſo too.
But to my ſelf reſerve what I will do.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: EPhraim, thou haſt made me a man, both without, witneſſe this ſword and within, witneſſe this precious book, which I have gotten al|moſt by heart already.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: But ſir, beware you fall not back again Into your childiſh follies: but go forwards In manly actions: for non progredi eſt regredi.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I know the meaning of that too, Ephraim. That's once a man and twice a childe. But if I turne childe again, while I have teeth in my head, ●'le give Mrs. Blithe leave to dig 'hem out with Sugar|plums, as ſhe almoſt did theſe two of 'hem yeſterday, with her knuckles. I would they ſtuck both in her bum for't, till I we●e married to her, and that ſhall be ſhortly, they ſay, I wo' not turne boy again for that trick.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope you will not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p:
Thou mayeſt be ſure on't Ephraim: for if I would turne boy again, I ha' not wherewithal to ſet up again. Thou ſaweſt that, aſſoon as I had taſted the ſweetneſſe of this delic●ous book here, I tore and burnt all my ballats, as well the godly as the ungodly. In my conſcience as many as might have furniſh't three Bartholomew Faires, and then for love of this ſword, I broke and did away all my ſtorehouſe of tops, gigs, b●l●s, cat and catſticks, pot-guns, key-guns, trunks, tillers, and all; and will I turne boy again canſt think? ye● I am half ſorry, being towards a wife, that I did
not keep 'hem for my children: ſome money might have been ſav'd by't. And that is a manly and a good husbandly conſideration, I take it. But hang covetouſ|neſſe: There comes not a mouth into the world, but there's meat for t; and if I finde 'em not play games, their mother will finde friends, that ſhall, for them and her ſelfe too

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I'm glad to heare ſuch good things to come from you,
And hope that now your judgment's ſtrong e|nough
To manage my affair. You know my minde, ſir.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Amardla Ephraim, 'twill be hard to compaſſe. For the old Knight will never let me have his Neece, unleſſe he have my mother. He meanes to truck for her, though, I confeſſe, I had rather call thee father then any man, I know, yet I know not how to bring it about, unleſſe he marry her firſt; and then ſhe be weary of him, and take thee afterwards to mend her match. I think it muſt be ſo, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Now you flie out again, that's as impoſ|ſible, as 'tis unlawful.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Peace, my mother comes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Where are you childe? Neh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I hear her neighing after me, I'le do all I can for thee, Amardla Ephraim.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Look you ●onne, what kinde Sir Swithin has ſent you. A dancing frog, you would think it were a|live, and a ballet of burning the falſe prophets before they be tried. And another fearful one of the new Antichriſt.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Hang bawbles, burn ballets, I am a man, and defie boyes tricks.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A ſudden change, I pray it be good.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Tell me of toyes? I have a ſword: offer me ballets? I have a book. Speak to me of Sir Swithin, I'le talk to you of Ephraim that gave me theſe bleſ|ſings; and is fitter to be my father, (ſo he is) then the fooliſheſt Knight of 'em all.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Bleſſe my ſonne from too much learning. That book has done him no good, I doubt. He talks and looks ſo wildly o'the ſudden.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A ha!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What book is't. Let me ſee it.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I'le tell you firſt. It is a book all of Bulls, Jeſts and Lies Collected by an A. S. Gent. Mother f'ſooth, there be ſuch things in it! If you never reade it, it is the rareſt book that ever you read in your life. Open it where you will, and you ſhall learn ſomething. As here now. One refuſing to eat Cheeſe|cakes, was ask't his reaſon. He told them he lov'd the fleſh well, but was afeard of the bones. Then here's the next to't. One asking whence Lobſters were brought: his fellow repli'd, one might eaſily know their countrey by their coat. They are fetch't from the red ſea. Now would I might never eat more of 'hem, as well as I love 'hem, if I know what Cheeſe-cakes were made of, or from whence Lobſters came be|fore.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is this your book-learning? In troth thou mak'ſt me laugh.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Laugh on, good Mother. And while you are in the merry mood, let me ſpeak a good word for E|phraim. I have a minde f'ſooth, becauſe he has made me a man, to make him my father, f'ſooth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! How now.
How durſt you firrah, move my ſonne in this? ha.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is it but ſo? ha!

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'ſooth hear him ſpeak. He can ſpeak Po|etry (he ſayes) as well as Knight Whimlbie. Speak Ephraim.

l.hi: Keeper in wedlock. Theſe did wiſely know,
Inferiour men beſt could their work below.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother f'ſooth, Is it not fine?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, more then ſo, I'le further go

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But you ſhall not, Sirrah. What, what! how now! Is't but up and ride? ha! Out of my doors thou varlet.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I muſt out too then, mother I am afraid, oh.—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Good Neh. be pacified, I'le give him a better anſwer.
sp.l: But not a word on't now, ſweet childe, I pray thee.
Here comes Sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I marry Sir Swithin. This is better then O Ma|dam, O—, when you waſh't your handkerchiefs in the ſuds, and then to wring hem out in Poetry.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p:
My tears with the memory of the dead are all fallen into Lethe; and nothing but joy left in me, ſinc my hopes are confirm'd in your lap. And hang
Poetry: I ſtudy profit now. Therefore, look you, Madam, here is a draught of my marriage-inſtrument to your lap.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: His inſtrument being drawn, I muſt put up my pipe and be gone.

sp.speaker: VVhi.
sp.p: And here is another draught for ſweet Maſter Nehemiah, for my Neece Blithes Joincture.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: O but ſhe ſayes ſhe will not have me.

sp.speaker: VVhi.
sp.p: When did ſhe ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Now, now, ſhe ſpat the word out of her mouth. And I ſay, if ſhe ha' not me, you ſhall whine both your eyes out before you have my mother; and ſee ne're the worſe, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: A croſſe marriage, or no marriage, I ſay ſtill.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ſay ſo too, ſonne, Sweet boy, be content.

sp.speaker: Whi. Blithe.
sp.p: You ſpoke well of him behinde his back: and made me think you lov'd him, and would marry him.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Behinde his back, I may do much to pleaſe you. But when I look upon him, he turnes my ſtomack worſe then a fool made of ſoure wilk.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Marry Gip, Mrs Queaſie, my ſonne's as ſweet as you, I hope, and as wiſe as you. And ſuck't as ſweet milk as ever the good Cow your mother gave.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Patience, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.p: I hope the croſſe marriage is croſt. This is untoward wooing.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Uds ſo! do you flirt out your unſavoury com|pariſons upon my ſonne?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Flirt not you at me, Madam, leſt I flirt your milk-ſop under the ſnotty noſe here.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Yes, and I have a ſword, and you ha' got ne're a one.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You wo' not will you, ha! Do you flie at him, ha!

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Fear not, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ephraim, ſave my boy.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Whi
sp.p: She ſhall not hurt him. Leave her to me, good Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I ever fear'd he was not long-liv'd he was ſo witty. And now I feare, ſhe will be the death of him. I would not he ſhould marry her for a million.

sp.speaker: Neh
sp.p: Say not ſo, mother. I love her better and better ſtill.
I never had play-fellow i my life, but we fell out and in agen.
And I muſt and will marry her, I take my death on't a|forehand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: O me! he is bewitch't to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Leave all to me, dear Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: As I am to you, I think, Sir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Let me alone with her: I'le win her, and he ſhall wear her▪ feare not. As ● was ſaying, Madam, ſhe ſpeaks as well of him behinde his back, as your owne heart can wiſh. And told me ſhe was content to mar|ry him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Behinde his back? did ſhe ſo?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes truly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Loe you there, mother, Let her marry me behind my back then: And when we are marri'd, I'le make her ſtick to't before my face, I warrant you; or if ſhe will make back-play. I'le play at nothing but back|gammons with her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, Heaven bleſſe thee, thou art but too good for her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Speak gently, Neece, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bli
sp.p: Madam, I hope your Ladiſhip ſhall finde me too good for him. If e're he has me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Ha! ſay you ſo?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She meanes in well-doing, Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay then, I thank you Mrs. Blithe. Aſſuring you that you ſhall be no way ſo good to him, but I will be as good to you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Agreed again of all hands. But look how ſhe turnes and keeps cut like my Sparrow. She will be my back Sweet-heart ſtill I ſee, and love me behind.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: She is yet raw, and has not much been abroad to ſee the manners of the time. In which my melan|choly has been her main hinderance. But Madam, there is now that is worth all our ſight and obſervation; A new Academy, where they ſay, the neweſt and moſt courtly carriage and behaviour is taught and pra|ctiſed both for young Gentlemen and women. Have you not heard on t?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes Sir Swithin; and that the French tongue is taught there with great alacrity; and my ſonne is wiſh't thither, but ſoft I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: But let him ſee it: at leaſt in our company it will embolden him; I mean to carry my Neece thither. I have been a Lover of Arts and Exerciſes; and know ſomewhat ſince my youth. Pray let us ſpend one houre of this afternoon there.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pardon me good ſir Swithin.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: But he ſhall not mother if you love me: for I mean to perfect my dancing there; and to learn French there; For I mean when I am married to travel into France. But I will firſt be perfect in the tongue I ſhall learne it the ſooner when I am there you know. Pray let us go to th' Acomedy, what dee call it?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: The Academy.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſonne? then come ſir Swithin. Come Mrs. Blithe, we will all go.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: I'le wait upon you, though my heart ſayes no.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O mine own heart! how near were we both fallen
Into the Gulf of Ruine?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Thanks for our delivery!
We were upon the brink of main deſtruction.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Was ever ſuch a Fr●end as this mine Vncle?
Pretending us his children too, and call'd us daugh|ters
To thoſe he bargain'd with to ſe●l our Maide head?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: 'Twas a moſt damnable practiſe ſie upon him.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And had the Monſieurs been as capable
Of our Virginities, as he was of.
Their moneys, how had we then reſiſted.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: By Venus (mine own heart) my Gentleman
Came up ſo cloſe to me, that if my voice
Had not been ſtronger then mine armes (O me!
I tremble fon it yet) I had been vanquiſh't,

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: But did you note the vertue of the Gentle|men?
When they were ſenſible of our feares and tears,
How gently they deſiſted and with what humanity,
When they perceiv'd how we had heen betrayd,
They pitied our conditions; and woo'd homditly
Our loves in way of marriage. Provided that
Our births and fortunes might no way diſparage
Theirs, being free and generous

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: I confeſſe
I love 'hem both ſo well, that if they prove
(As they pretend they are not) our inferiours
In blood and worth, I would take either of'em.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Troth (mine own heart) 'tis juſt the ſame with me.
I care not which I have. And mark a ſympathy,
How equally all our ●ffections ſtrike.
We both love them, they both love us alike.
But peace. Caſh, though he has done us good ſervice,
Muſt not know all. How goes it within Caſh?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And why Caſh pray. Ha' not you chang'd your names
From Joyce and Gabriella to Jane and Frances.
And is not your Uncle Strigood now become
Your father, by the name of Mr. Lightfoot
The nimble dancing Maſter? And muſt I ſtill
Carry the name of Caſh? and having loſt
My nature too, in having no caſh left?
(Pox o'the dice) call me Mr. Outlaſh.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: My father will fetch you home with an Inlaſh,
One o'theſe dayes.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: But after you, faire Miſtris,
Now to your queſtion for the ſquares within.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I with the Frenchmen, and my Uncle Stri|good.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Your father Lightfoot, you forget agen.
There's a drawn match made: For the Monſieurs
Have ta'ne their money again: And you have ſtill
Your Maidenheads, I hope. But to have heard
The coi●e they kept, the wrangle, and the ſtir;
And how the young Blades put the old one to't;
Would ha perplext you more then keeping of
Your Maidenheads from men you love.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: You cannot tell that.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: O how the old man chafes that you would offer
To make your mone to ●hem to move their pity,
And not to make his bargain good; and then
How they put home his baſeneſſe to him; to make ſale
Of his own blood and honour in his children.
(They knew they ſaid ſome parents in their coun|trey,
After their children were turn'd whores, would ſhare
To live upon the profits, but to ſell
Their ſoules before they were damned, fie; fie, fie, fie).
Till he confeſt indeed you were none of his.
But children of ſome friends of his deceaſt,
Left to his care ſor breeding; which he had
Plenteouſly given, and thought it might ſeem reaſon|able
To raiſe his money out of you agen.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: What an old devil is this?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Baſer and baſer ſtill.
The Monſieurs cri'd, and ſwore if they could ſinde
Your Parents were Gentle and vertuous,
Being their firſt Loves, they would marry you,
To free you from this miſerable thraldome.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Brave honeſt Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: Be adviſ'd though, Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Beware of Travellers, many paſſe abroad
For gallant fellowes that have run their countrey,
For picking pockets.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And ſome you know at home
For cozening their Maſters.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You are pleaſ'd.
But you have known my love; for Gabriella
Let'hem ſhare her betwixt 'hem. You and I
Made one, may ſoon make peace with the old man
At home.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: O Rogue! I'le tell you more anon Caſh.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, Monſieur Papillion.
And Monſieur Galliard, all friends, all friends.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: A greed, agreed, ſir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: And agree for me.
Agree poor tout.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Chear up your faces Girles.
'Twas but my trial of your chaſtity.
And ſince you have ſtood firme, I am proud of you.
Truſt me, 'twas but to try you.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Wee wee All, but for try. Trimount, tri|mount.
No more, but all for try: no man can tinck,
But'twas too very moſhe to take two hundred
Crowns for two puſillages, no, no was but
For try: but and ſhe had not ſqueek and ſcraſh too
Like to do leetel chat, I had Trimount
One, two, tree, five time, for all your try.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: VVhat's paſt let be forgot. According to
Agreement, Gentlemen, y'are now content
To joyne with us in Academick fellowſhip,
And for your paſtime profeſſe Art and Science,
As we do for our profit: y'are expert,
I finde; and ſhall winne wonder of our Nation,
To your own much delight out of their follies.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: And then for Gameſters, Gentlemen. If you●ll play.
I'le bring ye thoſe ſhall venture money enough.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: VVe are planted to our wiſh.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: All very good.
All very good; but I would ſee thee firſt.
VVhat Ladies will come here to practiſe complement.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: You are ſtill hot upon the female Monſieur Galliard
Monſieur Papillion here flies over ●hem.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, the newes?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: The old will to't.
As well as the young I ſee.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: To what Landlady?
sp.stage: He takes her aſide. And that while the young men and maids court and confer at tother ſide.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: To faſhion following;
A Reverend Lady
Of fifty five; and a Knight of threeſcore
And upwards, are come hither to learn faſhion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Do you know their names?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, yes: and them; 'tis that
Begets my wonder.
'Tis the Lady Neſtlecock, and one Sir Swithin VVhimlby.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: VVit be merciful unto us.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: The Ladies man's without: who came to know if the houſe were ready to entertain 'hem; do you know 'em Mr. Lightfoot?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I have heard o'th' Lady. Caſh, ſee if it be E|phraim.
He cannot know thee. Let him not away,
By any meanes, his not return to them may keep 'hem back.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I ſee him hither.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Landlady, is your husband come from duck|ing.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Yes, overjoy'd with the good ſport he has had.
He'll play th' good fellow then. Entreat him Caſh.
To help thee, put a cup or two upon
That fellow; and hear●ſt me, ſpice his cup,
I mean, grave Ephraims cup with this ſame powder,
'Twill lay him aſleep, and quickly.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I know the trick on't.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And Landlady, when the Knight and Lady come,
Say we are ready for 'em.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That I ſhall ſir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: 'Tis then an abſolute contract. I am yours.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: And I am yours as firme as faith can binde.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: To which we are de witneſſe. Be ſo for us,
I am her husband, And ſhe is my wife,
Speak you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: 'Fore Heaven, I do acknowledge it,
But ſir, the Church muſt be obſerv'd,

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: For that.
We'll ſend for one Miniſter that ſhall marry
Us all at once. One kiſſe till then ſhall ſerve.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well done Monſieurs, I no ſooner turn
My back, but you are on the Damoſels lips.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: A leetel in de honeſt way will ſerve,
But he ſhall know no-ting.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: On with your Maſques-Maids,
And take eſpecial heed you bluſh not through 'hem.
For here are ſome at hand will put us to't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: 'Tis not my father, nor my Lady Aunt?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I cannot promiſe you. Be bold and ſafe.
Beare it out bravely, or our ſchool breaks up
Immediately: and we are broke forever,
Beſides, there is no ſtartiug.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: That's enough
To make a coward fight, and mine own heart;
We muſt ſtand ſtoutly to't, we loſe our loves elſe.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.l: Well, I am arm'd.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Fall into complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I muſe we loſt my man thus.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: By your leave, ſir.
Are you the Regent of this Academy?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: I am ſir.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: And are thoſe of your Aſſiſtants.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes ſir, and all Profeſſors of Court-diſcipline,
By the moſt accurate, yet more familiar
Rules, then have ever yet been taught by any,
For quick inſtruction both of young and old.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: You promiſe very fairly. For us old ones,
We know and could have done things in our youth,
Which ſtill we have a minde to: but we leave
The practice to our young ones: Here's a paire
Would faine be at it. We'll pay their admittance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: But I'd be glad to ſee firſt by your leave,
Some probability of what they ſhall learn.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And reaſon good, good Madam. Pray obſerve there.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Fair ſtar of courtſhip, my unworthy humble ſelf, a Profeſt ſervant to the integrity of beauty, makes this
Clear teſtimony of your merits, that every eye that ſees you,
Owes you his heart for tribute, and that unjuſtly your beholders live, that live not in your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother f'ſooth, is not this French?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Peace ch●lde. Hear more on't.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: Noble ſir, you are ſo exactly deſerving in the opinion of all righteous judgements, that the leaſt ſyl|lable of your faire teſtimony, is able to re-edifie the ru|ines of a decayed commendation.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: The beſt that ever I heard, ſince I woo'd my Griſſel.

sp.speaker: Stri,
sp.p: Was not that a ſweet bout, ſir?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, it puts me in minde of ſome ſweet bouts I had with one before I married her.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: ●as he married my Siſter troe?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: I am forc't to give you over, Madam, you have ſuch a preventing and preoccupying wit in all things.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: That goes like Engliſh Mrs. Blithe. I could learn ſome of that me thinks.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Beſt tell your mother ſo; ſhe may rejoyce at it.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: There, Lady, was a taſte of ſweet comple|ment between perſons equally affected. May it pleaſe you now to let your ſonne paſſe upon this demoſel. Who being to her a ſtranger, and raw (as I imagine) in courtſhip, ſhall meet with reprehenſion, that may be for his inſtruction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do Neh. ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Put of your hat and ſay—.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What! and her masque on?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: That was well-ſaid. Why are they mask'd, I pray ſir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We are commanded it by the policy of wiſe authority; for feare young heires might fall in love with 'em, and ſink their fortunes.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You have well ſatisfied me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What ſhould I ſay to one I never ſaw.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: When I was young and bold, I would have ſaid, Lady, you are moſt auſpiciouſly encountred. And ſpeak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Lady, you are moſt ſuſpiciouſly accoutred, I ſpeak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Auſpiciouſly encountred man.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Auſpicouſly encountred woman, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I commiſerate your encounter. 'Tis a moſt hungry, verminous, impoveriſh't word ſir. It ſeems you are a ſtranger by't, to the Innovation of courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: What ſhould I ſay to that now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He's a weak ſcholar forſooth, and would be glad to learn.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: The acknowledgement of his weakneſſe is the firſt greece of gradation to perfection, and his glad|neſſe the ſcaling-ladder of reſolution.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray f'ſooth, can you teach me a complement to offer you ſugar-plums, and eat 'hem my ſelfe: to ſave my manners and my plums too?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What a wag it is?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What walking dunghil is this? made of the duſt ſwept from the houſe of ignorance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What, what! how now, ha? you are a Flapſe to terme my ſonne ſo, ha!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: O good Madam. This is but ſchool play.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I'le put her by her ſchool-tricks and no only ●nmask, but unskin her face too, and ſhe come over my heire apparent with ſuch Billingsgate Comple|ments.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Sweet Madam, no harm was meant, and no|thing ſaid in earneſt: 'Twas meerly but ſchool pra|ctice, but to ſhew the ſweet young Gentleman how he might be ſubject to the ſcorne of Court, before he be ſeen in Complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: 'Twas told your Ladiſhip before, that by repre|henſion he might finde inſtructiou.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Right Madam; For no Fencer learnes his Science before he receive ſome hits and knocks too: Oh, I have had many.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, I am ſatisfied, and pray, that my raſh er|rour may prove pardonable Lady

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Rather let me implore your mercy, Ma|dam—.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p:
'Tis well, 'tis well Lets hear an Interchange or two now, of complemental acknowledgement of
courteſies paſt betwixt Ladies, for the edification of ●his faire one, who ſeems not yet to have ta'ne notice of us, but looks o' the ground ſtill.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: 'Tis not to finde a feſcue, ſir, among the Ruſhes.
To pick out a leſſon in your criſſe-croſſe-row of comple|ment.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Sharp and ſudden. She has a good wit I ſee.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Ob erve, good Blithe, obſerve.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Can your poor ſervant expreſſe acknowledge|ment enough, Lady, for favonrs ſo inceſſantly heap't upon her, beſides the accumulation of many ſecret be|nefits?

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: I cannot but admire, Madam, your noble and illuſtrious Gratitude, that can give beauty to benefits of ſo low a birth and condition.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: O my Griſſel comes to my minde agen, ſhe was the gratefulleſt woman.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: If ſuch favours, Madam, ſhould paſſe under an humble name, Honour would grow idle, and a thankful Nature beguil'd of her emploiment.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You'●l make my zeale hereafter, too baſhful to ſerve your moſt curious acknowledgement.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Curious acknowledgement! There was a thrid drawn out.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am hound by many kindneſſes, Madam, to ce|lebrate the faire memory of you; as the trouble of your Coach twice in one day, beſides thoſe ineſtimable Jewels, the Monkey and Dormouſe your Ladiſhip ſent me.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: I would you could lend me a ſight of 'hem for|ſooth, I love ſuch things devoutly.

sp.speaker: Joy.
sp.p: You do but open a privie door to my thankful temembrance, Madam, for the bounty of your Squirrel and Paraquitoe.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.p: Fagh, ſhut that privie-door.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: And ſhut in the Squirrel and the Paraquitoe to be ſtifled, ſhall ſhe? O that I could ſee hem!

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Now Madam, and Sir Knight, Is not this neat and handſom?

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.p: Truly, truly, 'tis moſt admirable pretty.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Nay, if you heard our Lectures, ſaw our
Daunces.
Reliſh't our Muſick and harmonious voices,
Obſerv'd our Rules for faſhion and attire,
Our many exact poſtures and dimenſions,
Fit to be uſ'd by way of Salutation,
Of courteſie, of honour, of obeiſance,
To all degrees of man or womankind,
From the low bent of vaſſalage, to the head
Of towring Majeſty, you ſhould admire.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But do you reade and teach all theſe to your ſcholars?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: Stand forth, Monfieur Galliard. Stay w'are interrupted.
sp.l: Up maids, and quickly; or 'tis not your Masques
Can keep you undiſcover'd. Go, be ready,
With Muſick and your voices, when I call to yee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Why are we interrupted? pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Mother, it is my naughty Aunt, ſo 'tis▪

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No matter, ſonne, we'll take no notice of her.
sp.l: I wonder at the boldneſſe of the drudge though.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I can turne taile too, as well as the great La|dy. Hab.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And do ſo, Myſtreſſe, give her a broad|ſide.
sp.l: Well-ſaid, we'll make our partie good, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Sir, we have heard your Fame; and love your Arts.
〈◊〉 pray that our ambition be excuſ'd,
Which drew on our Intruſion.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: To me and to the place you are all welcom.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ſo to all I hope, chiefly to you,
Good Madam Dowager, hoping in good time
I may get good, by doing much good upon you
How likes your L●p●my complement.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you bring your rude companions to affront me? Are you ſo hot? you ſtir up your cinders before they be cak't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Still in the Kitchin-dialect.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No ruder then your ſelf, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I brought her, Madam,
sp.l: 〈◊〉 advance my ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Will you ſee me abuſ'd
●ir 〈◊〉, look to your Neece, the t'other talks to her.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Kinde merry Gentlemen, Madam, when I was young I would have done the like. Their com|ing hither, was as ours was to note th' inſtructi|ons
That are taught here. Pray ſir proceed. On with your exerciſe, that we may all be edified.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: We ſhall do ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But ſir, your Gentlewomen,
sp.l: That paſt upon our entrance where are they?

sp.p: Sir, they were call'd in haſte to private pra|ctice
sp.l: With ſome great Ladies in an upper room.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Umh—private practice. Well, I ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.p: And they being abſent, we ſhall for the pre|ſent
sp.l: Only deliver by theſe Gentlemen,
●●me heads of Sciences.
A Song, a Daunce, and then
Entreat you take a taſte of a collation.
And all moſt fairly welcome.
The heads of our chief Arts. Your ſilence, pray you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: The firſt is the due carriage of the body,
The proper motion of the head, hand, leg,
To every ſeveral degree of perſon,
From the Peaſant unto the Potentate;
To your ●nferiours how and when to uſe the Nod,
The Hum, the Ha, the Frown, the Smile,
Upon the fit occaſſion; and to your equals,
The exacteſt, neweſt, and familiar motions
Of eye, of hand, of knee, of arme and ſhoulder,
That are in Garbe, in Congee, Crindge, or Shrug,
In common Courteſie, or Complement,
Laſtly, for your Addreſſes to Superiours.
The Honours, Reverence, or Obeyſances,
Proper unto the quality or eſtate
Of perſon whatſoever. And ſo much
For carriage and behaviour. In the next place
You ſhall have rules for the more graceful wearing
Of your Apparel, with the natural Reaſons,
Why ſome mans hat does better in his hand
Then on his head, and why his coat hangs neater
Upon his elbow, then upon his back,
As alſo Reaſons for Tunes bringing up.
And marriages, together of the faſhions
Of man and woman, how his Caller, and her
Black-bag, came on together; how his pocket-comb
To ſpru●e his Perrule, and her Girdle-glaſſe,
To order her black paſhes, came together;
How his walking in the ſtreets without a cloak
And her, without a man came up together,
Of theſe, and of a hundred more the like.
We ſhall demonſtrate reaſons and inſtructions.
Shall render you moſt graceful in each faſhion.
The next are skills in inſtruments, ſong and dancing

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Enough, thoſe ſhall be made familiar to you
By voice and action inſtantly. A Song there.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Admirable pretty ſtill.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Are theſe your Gentlewomens voices, ſir?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: They are

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What do you keep 'hem up like Nuns,
To ſing and not be ſeen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Not alwayes ſir.
But may it pleaſe yee Gentlemen and Ladies,
Now to obſerve the practice of our feet
In active dancing.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: That came I to learn,
And to ſpeak French, do you think ſir, you can bring
My mouth to handle the French tongue handſomly.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He's apt to learn, ſir, I can tell you that.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Yes. I ſhall bring his Mout to it. But his Mont is yet a leetel too wide. But he ſhall have ſome of de wa|ter datde woman uſe for anoderting, to bring it bet|ter together, and he ſhall ſpeak like de Franſh Lady.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.p: Pray ſir, if you can like the Ladies daughter of Paris properlie.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. thou knoweſt the way.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder ſir, 'Mongſt all your Arts and Sci|ences
You have ſo little judgement in a face,
Does his mouth appear wide to you? what falſe glaſſe
Are your eyes made of?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What you mean?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, friend.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Pray ſir take no offence. Here was none meant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Slander is no offence then. He has injur'd,
By breathing an aſperſion on that face,
The life of beauty, and the ſoule of ſweetneſſe.
Wide mouth Y—.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.l: Begar Monſieur, you ſhall no point out mouth,
No, nor out-face the Frenſh man with your great Bull-beef, and Muſtard Engliſh looks.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, gentle Val. forbear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le ſtop.
This mouth that knowingly ſayes he dares except
Againſt a tittle of his face or perſon.
But as he is an ignorant ſtranger, and
I muſt reſpect the company. I forbear.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: However ſir, I can but thank your love in 't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now it works in her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Pardon my plainneſſe, Madam.
I never was ſo ta'ne with Maſculine beauty.
And till I winne a woman that is like him,
Or has been like him, I can but languiſh.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: They told me I was like him, when I was younger.
And let me tell you y' are a comely Gentleman.
And be you but as honeſt as y' are handſom, you de|ſerve well.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ʋmh, 'tis a hard matter to bring thoſe ends to|gether.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Mother f'ſooth. Here's a man now for you to make my father!
Beyond the Knight or Ephraim!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Were I free from the old Knight, I could look well upon him.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Come ſervant, come away.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By no meanes, Myſtreſſe, I do but ſooth her up to jeare her for vou.
If you out-ſtay her not, you loſe your honour.
She'll brag ſhe has out-look't you. If you ſtart.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Nay, and ſhe go to that, I hope I can,
Look as ill favouredly as her ſelfe, or a better
Woman then ſhe, and ſtay in ſpight of her, hah.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, Myſtris, Madam ſhall I tell you.
But I would pray you not to ſtorme, but laugh at it.
She ſayes you are no match for me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And knowing I aim at none but ſome great wi|dow.
Tells me ſhe knows her husband's but ſhort-liv'd.
I fear ſhe means to break his heart.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Say you ſo?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No words, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: ●et more whiſpering.
Pray Madam let us go. Neece come away,
For I fear Madam, as you wiſely doubted,
This is no companie for us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Sir, I hope.
I am not yet ſo tied, but I may ſafelie
Uſe my own ●reedom, I'le go when I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: O Griſſel, Griſſel, when would'ſt thou have ſaid ſo?

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Loves power, I hope, hath wonne on deſtinie,
T' appoint this day for my delivery.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir Swithin,—Ladies—we have yet
Dauncing to come, and a Collation promiſ'd.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Yes Gallants, now w' are readie, we but ſtayed for this fourth man here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O Camelion.
Where is your wife? I hope your je louſie.
Locks her not up.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Piſh Honi ſoit. I hate it.
No, ſhe has been preparing of a banquet,
Which now is ready for you, worthy Mr. Lightfoot,
And your faire company; jealouſie I defie
The ba●e horne A gue, Mr. Askal I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What does he call you? Raſcal?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Askal Madam.
My name is Askal. But the R in Maſter
Runs in●o't ſo, that ſometimes it ſounds doubtful.
I muſt be Knighted, Euphoniae gratia.
Sir Valentine Askal will come fairly off.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now note me Mr. Askal, and tell me if ever jealous man came ſo lightly off.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Sir, your collation ſtayes.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: 'Tis well, Gallants and Ladies
Wilt pleaſe you enter.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed, of all ſides.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: INhoſpitable! 'tis inhumane, paſt
The cruelty of infidels.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou ſpeak'ſt
But thine own barbarous cruelty, hollow Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Abominable hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Cunning Villain.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Fie Gentlemen, forbear this unknown lan|guage.
And either ſpeak to others underſtanding,
If you ſpeak Juſtice:

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Give me then my ſonne.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Thou haſt thy ſonne, give me my ſonne and daughter.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen, if you'll not hear each o|ther, yet both hear me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I pray Captain ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You had his ſonne to foſter; he your daughter.
You faithfully affirme you ſent his ſonne
For England a moneth ſince.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: And mine own with him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You have confeſt you put away his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And mine own with her, through her diſobe|ence.
But 'twas upon advertiſement by letter,
That he had firſt caſt off my ſonne to an
Untimely death.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Some Villain forg'd that letter,
And let me tell you ſir, though in your houſe,
Lafoy's an honeſt and a temperate man.
You are raſh and unadviſ'd, what Lafoy ſpeaks
I will maintain for truth: what you have done
I wiſh you could make good; But I may fear
You are mark't out by your own wilfulneſſe,
The ſubject of much woe and ſad misfortune.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not what I am; but did you know
The number, and the weight of my afflictions,
You could not chide me thus without ſome pity.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Indeed I pity you, and now y'are calme,
Know that Lafoy ſent his ſonne over with yours,
And but for ſome affaires he had with me,
I'th Iſle of Wight he had embarqu'd himſelf
With them, and brought hem to you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: There's hope then yet
That my boy lives.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And is come over feare not.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You comfort me, and now Lafoy y' are wel|come.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: But to what comfort, having loſt my daugh|ter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Loſt or loſt not, mine's with her. And I
purpoſe now to be ſad no longer. For I think
I ha' loſt my wife too, there's a ſecond comfort.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Take an example here Monſieur Lafoy,
And ſhake of ſadneſſe; mirth may come unlook't for.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I ha' loſt a ſonne too, a wilde roaring Lad,
About this town. And if I finde not him,
I doubt not I ſhall finde, that he has ſpent me
A hundred pound ſince I laſt heard of him.
By the way ſir, I ſent you a bill of change
Laſt moneth, to pay a hundred pieces for me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Twas paid. I have your bill for my diſcharge.
How now?
Ha' you found your Myſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Nor tidings of her, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: She has found then ſome good exerciſe, I doubt not.
That holds her ſo.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, there's a Gentleman
Craves inſtant ſpeech with you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Who? or whence comes he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He will be known to none before he ſees you.
And, when you ſee him, he ſayes he thinks you'll know him.
He's a brave gallant, one o'the Alamodes,
Nothing but French all over.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fetch him me quickly,
It is my ſonne. Grammercie mine own heart,
That waſt not light ſo ſuddenlie for nothing,
Pray Gentlemen, who e're you ſee, name no man
To me, unleſſe I ask you. He comes, he comes.
I'm grown a proper man. Heaven make me thank|ful.
Juſt ſuch a ſpark was I at two and twenty,
Set cloathes and faſhion by. He thinks to try
If I can know him now. But there I'le fit him.
With me ſir is your buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I preſume
You do not know me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: As well as he that got him.
Pray Gentlemen keep your countenances. Not know you ſir?
'Tis like I may have known you here to fore,
But cannot readily collect; perhaps
You are much chang'd by Travel, Time, and Bra|very,
Since I laſt ſaw you. There he may finde.
I partly gueſſe, but will not know him yet.
Good Geutlemen ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What ailes he troe.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: He knowes me, I feare, too ſoon. If now my plot faile, and he have a Counterplot upon me. I am laid up.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Do you not know me yet ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Know you, or know you not ſir, what's your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: You ſometimes had a ſonne ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes to me.
I had ſir. But I hear he's ſlain in France.
And farewel he. Mark how I handle him.
And what ſir of my fonne?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: He's dead you ſay.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I mufe the Knave askes me not bleſſing though.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: But to ſupplie his loſſe you have a daugh|ter
That may endear a ſonne, ſir, to your comfort.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whither now flies he trow! Sir, do you know her.
Or where to finde her?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Firſt upon my knees
Let me implore your pardon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Now he comes home: And I can hold no longer.
My bleſſing boy, thou meaneſt. Take it, and wel|come
To a glad father. Riſe, and let my teares,
If joy confirm thy welcom.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I may not riſe yet ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No? why? what haſt thou done? where's young Lafoy?
My true friends ſonne here? whom I now muſt lock
Up in theſe armes, amidſt a thouſand welcomes.
Where's the young man?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I know not who you mean ſir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Diſtract me not.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: I feare you are deſtraught.
I know not him. How ſhould he know my ſon.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Let me look nearer.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Sir, I am your Prentice.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Whow—whow, whow, who—my Thieſe and Runaway.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Prav ſir afford me hearing.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, your cauſe
Requires a Judges hearing.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: I have put me
Into your hands, and not without much hope,
To gaine your pardon, and your daughters love.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis roundly ſpoken. Gentlemen, I'le tell you.
This gallant youth, has gallanted away
A thouſand pound of mine.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: For your advantage ſir: For
By this way
Of Gallantry, as you call it, I have travell'd
Through the Reſorts and Haunts publike and pri|vate
Of all the Gallants in the Town. In brief
I have found your daughter, where ſhe had been loſt
For evet in your brother Strigoods hands.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Canſt bring me thither?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Is my daughter with her?

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Madam Gabriella, the French Damſel's there.
And others, men and women, whom you'll know when you come there.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Good ſir, lets haſten thither.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You'll aid me, ſirs?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes, with our lives and fortune.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be fearleſſe Lady, and upon my life,
Honour, and faith; you are ſecure from danger.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Sir, I have put me in your hands you ſee
So liberally that I may feare to ſuffer,
If not a cenſure, yet a ſuppoſition
Of too much eaſineſſe, in being led
So ſuddenly ſo farre towards your deſire.
But my opinion of your nobleneſſe
Joyn'd with your Proteſtation, pleads my pardon
At leaſt it may, the wretchedneſſe conſidered,
To which I was enthrall'd.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: It is not more my love
Unto your vertue, and your faire endowments.
Then pity in me labours your releaſe.
Nor is it rather to enrich my ſelf.
Then to ſave you from ſo immenſe a danger,
As you had fallen into by yielding under
Your Uncles weakneſſe in ſo fond a match.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: Bleſſe me from being fool-clog'd.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now you are free.
If you can think your ſelf ſo, and but yield
Unto my preſent Counſel.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do ſo Lady
Before you are miſt within. Here is the Cloſet,
And here's the Key in your own hands, And pre|ſently I'le fetch a Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You ſee
I ſtill deal fairlie w'ye; and give you power
To keep guard on your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bli.
sp.l: And yet I yield
My ſelf your priſoner.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: In: ſome body comes.
She will be yours. And let me tell you, ſir,
I wiſh you as much joy with her, as I
Have with my Cock.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: You have befriended me
In this good enterpriſe: And one good turne
Requires another. And now for that I told you,
Touching your wife, your Cock you ſo rejoyce in.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Alas. alas, good Gentlemen, you would fain
Ha' me be jealous. Honi ſoit, y'are ſhort.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Stand by and obſerve.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do you begin to boggle,
And when I ſend for twenty pieces, do you
Send me but ten?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Nay mark.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I pray,
What have I had in all by your account.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: At ſeveral times, you have had fifty pounds of my poor husbands money.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What's that to the free pleaſure of my body
Which muſt afford you ſweet and luſtie payment?
You froward Monkey. But perhaps you ha' got
Some new-found Horn-maker, that you may think,
Deſerves your husbands money better, for
Doing his Journey-work, one o'the Monſieurs,
Or both perhaps i'th' houſe here under's Antlers,
It muſt be ſo, why elſe of all the town,
Muſt I be one o'th' laſt that muſt take notice
Of your new College here, your brazen face Col|lege
Of feates and fine fagaries? do you grow weary of me?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Do you grow wilde? ſpeak lower, do you mean to undo me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will tother fifty pound undo thee, I have loſt
All that I had within among your Monſieurs.
And you muſt yield ſupply, or loſe a friend
Of me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What a way would ſo much money have gone
In betts at the ducking pond?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Will no leſſe ſerve your turn then fifty?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No leſſe. All makes (you know) but a juſt hun|dred.
And there I'le ſtick; and ſtick cloſe to thee too,
Elſe all flies open. What care I who knows
Your credits breach, when you reſpect not mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis too well known already; All●s too open.
My houſe, my purſe, my wife, and all's too open.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: O me, undone.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Was ever loving husband
So much abuſd?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Enquire among your neighbours.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Be patient man.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O thou cloſe whore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take heed, ſir, what you ſay.
Eene now you ſaid ſhe was too open, ſir.
Y'are in two tales already.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I feare he's mad
Or jealous, which is worſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Piſh, Honi ſoit.
He jealous, he defies it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do you deride me?
Sir, you can witneſſe with me, he confeſt
Receipt of fifty pounds my wife has lent him,
(Falſe woman that ſhe is) for Horn-making,
Job Journey-work.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I know.
(At leaſt I think) I am deceiv'd in both.
My money and thy honeſty, but the Lawes
In both ſhall do me right, or all ſhall flie for't.
I'le inſtantly to councel.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Hear me firſt.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: By all meanes hear her firſt. Pray grant her that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I dare not look on her, leſt I be tempted
To yield unto my ſhame and my undoing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Will you not heare your Cock, your Nanſie,
Nanny Cock.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Time was you would not ha' denied me that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nor any thing, if my Cock had but ſtood upon't.
Such was my love, but now,

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: But now y'are jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Have I not cauſe?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Here's tother fifty pieces, take 'hem ſir.
They are full weight, and truly told.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Brave wench.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: If you will law, ſir, you ſhall law for ſome|thing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: What doſt thou mean?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I hope ſhe'll humble him ſo,
That he ſhall keep our chamber-door for us,
While we get boyes for him. A dainty Rogue,
She tempts me ſtrongly now. Would ſhe would call me
About it preſently.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: That money ſir
May ſerve to countenance you among the Gameſters
Within, that blew you up. The Lady widow
May think the better of your credit too,
Being ſo good i'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le ſtreight amongſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Councel me not ſir. All my joyes are gone.
I cannot think now what a ducking pond
Can be good for, except to d●own me in't.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Alas, poor man, I was in this too buſie.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Stay, you ſhall promiſe me before my hus|band,
That you will never more attempt my chaſtity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That bargaine's yet to make. Though before him
I may ſay much, I will not ſtand to that
For all the wealth he has.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You ſhall proteſt
Then, fairly, as you are a Gentleman
You never have enjoy'd me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I like that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, no, I cannot ſafely, for in that
I ſhall ſurrender up my intereſt
In's houſe; and he may warne me out on't. No,
Take heed o' that. 'Tis not his tother hundred
Shall make me ſlip that hold.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am loſt again.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: What a bold thief is this! Pray heare me, ſir.
You may remember that I ask't you once
What Countreyman you were.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, when you firſt caſt your good liking on me, and I told you.
sp.l: O'th' Iſle of Wight: And what o' that?

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: And you
Call Captain Hardyman, their father-in-law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You wrong me baſely, to ſay I call him any thing; for he gives me nothing.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You wrong him baſely. Look you, Can you reade.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I had done ill to venter (as I ha' done)
On Salisbury plain elſe. Hah, what's here
sp.p: That daughter, I ſent you order to receive for me an hundred pounds. If you finde that your brother the Spendthrift Val. Askal, (Zookes that I) be in any want, furniſh him according to your own diſcretion.
sp.l: I am Val. Askal, where's the money? My hundred
pound, ha' you't.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: It ſeems a Siſter of yours had it.
Ha' you a ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: He had a daughter by my mother, but
He plac●d her out a childe, I know not where
Where's that young whore trow? Hannah I think
her name was. Hang me if 〈◊〉 know directly.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My wives name's Hannah, ſir.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I am that ſiſter, brother, but no whore.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Now Val. your brags to make men think you lay with her.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: You have your hundred pound ſir. Look you, husband.
This is my fathers letter which you wrote on.
That which you dar'd the devil and Clerks to coun|terfeit, reade your own hand.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I muſt admire this woman.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Do'ſt think I did not know thee.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: No ſir, nor would I that you ſhould,
Till I had foil'd you in your courſe,
And had my will to make my husband jealous.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Cock, my Cock again, my Nanny cock,
Cock-all my Cock-a-hoop, I am overjoy'd,
See, ſee thy father too.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the woman.
To whom I paid your money.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis my daughter—.
My bleſſing on you.—What are you here too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And ask you bleſſing too. Your hundred pound Has bound me to't. Heaven bleſſe you, Here's halfe one ſtill, yes, and the better halfe, for tother's ſpent.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: O y'are a great good husband.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I would be one. And here's a good rich wi|dow
Now in the houſe, your countenance may help me,
My Siſter and my Brother both can tell you,
How orderly and civilly I live.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O wag.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: 'Tis like ſir, I ſhall prove your Furtherer.
What is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That Merchants Siſter, and a Lady ſir.
I would not have him heare.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: Well talk aſide then.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: In that I'm partly ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I love you ſir,
And waited on your wife but as your Sp●e,
For feare he might have led her to more folly.

sp.speaker: Mat:
sp.l: But ſaw you not two ſuch Damſels here?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Here are
Some in the houſe that would not be ſeen by us.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Becauſe they thought you'd know 'hem.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And if that
Old fellow be your brother Strigood, tis moſt ſtrange

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You know not him here do you?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: No not I.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis my man Caſh.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Moſt wonderful.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We ſhall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Pray haſte ſir, to diſcovery: I would f●ine
Once ſee my daughter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I would ſee a little
The faſhions o'the houſe firſt.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Pray obſcure
Your ſelves in that by room there, where you may
See and hear all that paſſes, nor can any
Paſſe out o'th' houſe without your notice.
The Gentlemen and I will mix again
With the Society, if they pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Agreed.
Within Strigood. Where are you Gent'emen?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Come away Val.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Is not that the Hell-hounds voice?

sp.speaker: Caſh
sp.l: Yes, 'tis your brother.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Good Captain go with us upon diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: I'le ſeat you to ſee all, and be unſeen.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Do ſo good Cock. Do ſo now ſir, I'le fetch the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, you have loſt ſuch ſport, the
Lady
And Merchants wife have been by th' eares.

sp.speaker: Caſh
sp.l: Could not
The old Knight part 'hem?

sp.speaker: Stri
sp.l: He has done his beſt,
And almoſt loſt his eyes in the adventure
Betwixt the Furies tallons▪

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: But are they friends agen?

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: And deep in complement.
Our ſchool affords no ſuch in act or language.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Siſter, Indeed I am too much your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Pray Madam let me ſerve you truly truly.
I'le be your ſervant for a yeare and a day

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed you wrong your ſelf, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am your ſervants ſervant, and will ſerve
Under your Ladiſhips Cook to do you ſervice.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Indeed you may not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If I may not be
Accepted for your houſhold ſervant, let me
Become your Chare-woman▪ in any office
From Cupboard to (loſe-ſtool, I can do all
To do your Ladiſhip ſervice.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.l: This now ſavours of Complement indeed.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: In ſooth, 'tis ſooth, forſooth the tale I tell you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Well acted mother.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Y' are too obſequious
Good gentle Siſter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am ſhort of good.
Gentle I grant I am, for I bite no body,
Command me then ſweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And very well acted Nant.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: O you ſhall pardon me▪

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: I am no Pope, for your ſake would I were.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Your courteſie o'recomes me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: O not ſo.
I wiſh it could forſooth, would it were better for you.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Exceeding well acted o'both ſides.
Mother and Aunt f'ſooth, Amardla you have done't
Better then the two School-Myſtreſſes to d●y
Could do their Whatſhicomes, their Complements
I think you call 'hem. But I ha' loſt my Myſtreſſe
To complement withal. Mrs. Bli●he Tripſhort
Has out-ſtrip't me, Amardla that ſhe has.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where's he● wiſe Uncle ſhould ha' look't to her.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: He's crying all about the houſe for her,
But cannot finde her. How ſhall I have her now?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt not have her boy, ſhe's naught.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Then he's
Naught too. You ſha'nt have him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Nor will, I feare not.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Think of the Gentleman, mother that out-fac'd
The Frenchman for me. I would you had a thouſand ſuch in France now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: God-a-mercy boy.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Peace, hear a little more.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Sir; come away.
I have found a careleſſe Curate, that has nothing but a bare Coat too looſe ſhall chopt't up preſently. And give him but a piece, he'll fear no Cannon.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I am bound to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Whither goes he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No matter, let him go t'untruſſe perhaps.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: I ſay ſhe is i'th houſe.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's gone, ſhe's gone.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: She's flowen out of a window, or chimney-top then.
I'm ſure I wrtch't the door with epen eyes
E're ſince you entred, as my Lady charg'd me,
Leſt her childe might ſlip out to play i th' ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: And I am here you ſee. He cannot ſee
He has no more eyes then a ſucking pig,
And yet he weeps like a roaſted one.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I am abuſ'd,
And r●nder me my Neece,
You have ſtolne her for your ſonne.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My ſonne defies her,
As I do you, old whining wither'd fellow,
That has no moiſture in him but for teares.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That is my Cue. A young well govern'd man
Were fitter, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: Where have you been ſervant?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I ſpeak to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My Lady, I think you ſaid.
Are you ſo ſtout ſir▪ hah?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I rather think he playes the cunning hypocrite
With his falſe teares, and packt her hence himſelf

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My Lady mindes you not, and I can learn
To give you a broad ſide too.

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Madam, that cannot be, for I have ſeen
All that went out, or came into the houſe▪
Since you. Here came a Church man in ere while.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: A Churchman! then I feare ſhe's clbſely mar|ried unto her wo and mine.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: Perhaps to me.
Behinde my back you ſaid ſhe would do ſo.
And before him came in your brother Matchil.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: My brother, who her husband?

sp.speaker: Eph.
sp.l: Yes, with others.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.l: My husband, I think you ●aid What a foule houſe theſe waſhing dayes make?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis no Jeſt Now ●●dies let me tell you,
And ſad Sir Swithin; pray lend all your eares.

sp.speaker: Stri.
sp.l: Caſh, we are betray●●Caſh if we be not nimble.
I ſmell a Fox. Hy thee up quickly Caſh,
And hurry down the wenches We'll make bold with
My Ladies Coach to hurry us away.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But not too faſt, Go ſir, fetch down the wenches.
Thou ſhameleſſe Reprobate. Doeſt thou hang thy head now?
I'le take a courſe to hang the reſt o'thee.
Your Ladiſhips well met at the new ſchool.
So is your Chare-woman. Ha' you profited
By the devils doctrine here? you weep ſin Swithin
For the iniquity of the times.

sp.speaker: Neh.
sp.l: You mean
His Neece, pray Vncle did you meet her,
She's gone away too, after my Couſin Joyce,
And the French maid, I think, ſhe is here agen.
Amardla, wipe your eyes, and look Sir Swithin,
The tother honeſt Gentleman has found her.
And let him take her for his paines for me.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I thank your love. But ſir, 'tis your conſent
We only ſeek.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir Swithin, let 'em have it,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman I would have ſpoke for:
In birth, in meanes, in perſon every way
Deſerving her. Take him upon my word.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: And Madam, ſince you ſtick but upon Joyn|cture,
Having heard lately well of his husbandry.

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.l: Thank a good ſiſter, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hard.
sp.l: I will ſecure you
Three hundred pounds a year, your brother knows me.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: With make good his word. Agree by your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Upon theſe termes, 'tis like we ſhall agree.
Sir Swithin are you pleaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Pleaſ'd or diſpleaſ'd.
It ſeems they are married.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, I aſſure you,
I ſaw their hands joyn'd, and I heard 'hem both
Anſwer the Prieſt.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I will no longer whine.
Heaven give you joy, As y'are your owne, y' are mine.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There are more weddings i'th' houſe, your daughters,
Are linck't by this time to the two young Frenchmen.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: His daughters? ours I fear? what French? where are they?
sp.stage: Enter Caſh, two ſonne's, Joy, Gab.

sp.speaker: Caſh.
sp.l: Here ſir, undone I feare.

sp.speaker: Mat,
sp.l: What are you married.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Jun: Sir, ſhe is mine, I muſt and will main|tain it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. And ſhe is mine.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: This is your ſonne. And this
Is mine.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: This is your daughter. And this mine. Each married to her brother.

l.hi: Jun. Mon Pere Je deſire veſtre Benediction Jour pour moy & ma fennue.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: You are loſt children all, was ever thread
By fate ſo croſſely ſp●n, ſo croſſely wed?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not how to Bleſſe you, or to look
On your inceſtuous eyes.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.l: Jun. What is dat Inceſt,
We have commit noting, we have no time,
Since we were marry for ſo much as kiſſe,
Begar no point ſo much as but one kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Be not diſmay'd. Theſe marriages are none.
The errour of the perſons nullifies
The verbal ceremony; and 'tis well
They paſt not unto further rites: I'le finde
A lawful way to clear all this. And then
As you and they conſent, they ſhall exchange
And marry in due order.

sp.speaker: Laf.
